August 01, 1916: Colonel H. J. Slocum of the Thirteenth Cavalry has been exonerated by the Secretary of War of blame in connection with Francisco Villa's raid on Columbus, N.M., last March. Colonel Slocum was in command of the American troops at Columbus, and there has been a great deal of unofficial criticism of the apparent circumstance that his forces were surprised by the Villistas. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB081EFD355B17738...

From daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2013/01/the-1903-m-orme-wi... Note: The "Wilsons" mentioned are Marshall Orme Wilson and his wife Carrie (Caroline Schermerhorn Astor) 'On the afternoon of Saturday February 2, 1916, the Wilsons hosted “a most successful entertainment…for the benefit of the students of the Ecole des Beaux Arts of Paris who are at the front and also for the benefit of their families,” reported The Sun. The affair was arranged by the New York architects who had been educated in Paris. A stage was constructed in the Wilson’s ballroom. The first part of the program was a concert during which Joseph Pizzarello played piano solos including compositions of Grieg and Godard; Albert Spalding played violin solos, and soprano Mlle. Lina Dilson of Brussels sang French songs. In the second part the Theatre Francais presented a one-act comedy entitled “Suzy.” '

Charles Young (March 12, 1864 – January 8, 1922) was the third African-American graduate of West Point, the first black U.S. national park superintendent, first black military attaché, first black to achieve the rank of colonel, and highest-ranking black officer in the United States Army until his death in 1922. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Young_(United_States_Army)

"On March 9, 1916, the [United States Army] 13th Cavalry was in Columbus, New Mexico which was raided by Pancho Villa. Eight soldiers and ten civilians were killed. Under General John J. Pershing, the regiment fought in the Mexican Expedition from 1916 to 1917, which was a response to the attack on Columbus. On April 12, 1916, about 100 men of the 13th Cavalry engaged Mexican federal troops in the Battle of Parral. During the fighting, two Americans were killed and six others were wounded. However, they defeated the Mexicans, killing at least a dozen of them or possibly many more.[2] The 13th Cavalry remained ready near the Mexican border until 1921. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/13th_Cavalry_Regiment_(United_States)
artolog, I think you're correct. This does appear to show the 13th Cavalry in or around Columbus after Villa's raid. I will ask to update the catalog record.

The Washington times. (Washington [D.C.]), 18 May 1909. Page 3, column 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1909-05-18/ed-... lists Fannie Schnelle as one of five Scandinavian women arriving in New York en route to the International Suffragists Congress in Toronto. The [New York] sun., December 26, 1915, page 1, col 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1915-12-26/ed-... names Mrs. Fanny Schnelle, a member of the town concil of Bergen as a delegate to a neutral conference associated with Henry Ford's peace mission to Europe. digitalarkivet.no/sab/bergensposten2/gymnast.htm has a photo of a Fanny Schnelle (also born in 1866) who appears to have been a gymnast and could easily be the same woman (rather younger).

The 1915 Journal of Proceedings of the One Hundred and Twenty-Fifth Session of the Rhode Island Episcopal Convention books.google.com/books?id=JKE9AAAAYAAJ mentiond the Rev F.W. Crowder several times, including as Delegate to the Synod of New England. Perhaps the reason for his being in the Bain file at this time is that (as reported on page 79) he rtansferred to the Diocese of New York in April 1916. His name appears to be Frank Warfield Crowder and he had been Rector of Grace Church, Providence.

The 1890 photograph of Frank Warfield Crowder at archives.dickinson.edu/image-archive/frank-warfield-crowd... could certainly be the same man. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=87231527 gives him as born on June 6, 1869 and dying on Sept 27, 1932 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._James%27_Episcopal_Church_%28Ne... is the parish he moved to in 1916, and he stayed there (St. James Episcopal Church, New York City) until 1932, the year he died. His NYT obituary (Sept 28, 1932) -- [needs subscription] select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30A17FD3A551673... indicates that he died of "heart disease" while still rector of St. James.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romania_during_World_War_I indicates that "In 1915 Lieutenant-Colonel Christopher Thomson, a fluent French speaker, was sent to Bucharest as British military attaché on Lord Kitchener's initiative to bring Romania into the war. Once there he quickly formed the view that an unprepared and ill-armed Romania facing a war on two fronts would be a liability, not an asset to the Allies. This view was brushed aside by Whitehall, and he signed a Military Convention with Romania on 13 August 1916." and "The Romanian government signed a treaty with the Allies on August 17, 1916, and declared war on the Central Powers on August 27."

That's "Henni" not "Henri" Forchhammer, pictured here: see also: An online Danish biographical encyclopedia provides information on most of the people in this photo. It identifies Carl Frederik Simony Thalbitzer (1876-1970) as a Danish economist and journalist who participated in the neutral peace conference in Stockholm in 1916. www.denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Samfund,_... Olaf Forchhammer (1881-1964), Henni's brother, was an engineer involved in many pacifist activities and causes. www.denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Naturvide... A.F. Lamm (Aron Frederik Lamm) (1856-1928) was a stockbroker and politician active in social causes. The biographical entry does not specifically link him to the Stockholm Mediation Conference. www.denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Samfund,_... The man on the right is identified as Asfred Bajer. I can't find much information on him, but an ancestry site identifies him as the eldest son of the Danish pacifist and politician Fredrik Bajer, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1908. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fredrik_Bajer www.mytrees.com/newanc/Other/Died-1871/Ba/Bajer-family/As... Likewise, there is no M. Klausen in the encyclopedia, but there is K.M. Klausen , Kristoffer Marqvard Klausen ,(1852-1924), a politician involved in many social causes similar to the aim of the Mediation Conference. www.denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Samfund,_... An article on the Neutral Conference for Continuous Mediation lists Kristoffer Marqvard Klausen as a Danish delegate to the Central Committee. archive.org/stream/jstor-20667582/20667582#page/n1/mode/2up

The revolution that deposed the monarch in Portugal was in 1910 -- see en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Portugal. March 9, 1916 was the day Germany declared War on Portugal in WWI. See www.history.com/this-day-in-history/germany-declares-war-... Perhaps Bain dug up earlier photos for use after this and that's why a "revolution" photo is in this batch.

About the revolution in Portugal of 1910 see also en.wikipedia.org/wiki/5_October_1910_revolution There never was a German invasion in Portugal, but a battle between Portuguese and German forces in Belgium. I think these photographs are just mislabelled.

A room in the Palácio das Necessidades in Lisbon. "On 5 October 1910, during the Republican Revolution, the palace, because it was the official residence of the king, Manuel II, was shelled by the cruiser Adamastor, one of the ships stationed in the Tagus River. The salvoes caused some damage to the Palace, and one of the bomblets even reached the king's private quarters on the first floor, but he had taken refuge elsewhere on the palace grounds." The Palácio Foz in Lisbon Streetview: maps.google.com/maps?q=38.715849,-9.141628&ll=38.7154...

"The neo-classical Palácio Foz was designed by the Italian architect Francisco Xavier Fabri and built shortly after the great earthquake in 1755, for the Marquês de Castelo Melhor. It was purchased by the Marquês de Foz in 1886 when it received the first of many facelifts. It now houses, amongst other things, one of Lisbon’s Tourist Information centres and an art gallery. It is magnificently decorated internally and the ballroom features outstanding paintings by Columbano Bordalo Pinheiro (1857-1929), one of the leading painters of his generation and a master of realism in Portugal." www.aportugalattraction.com/portugal-attractions/palcio-f...

www.gmcs.pt/palaciofoz/download/pt/palacio-foz.pdf, page 59 says that "in 1904, it became the quarters of the North-American legation, which stayed there for an unknown period of time." The North-American Legation quarters were on the 1st floor of the Palace (page 47f).

Ohio Democratic politician, strong ally of Woodrow Wilson, and appointee of Wilson for Secretary of War, a position in which he served from March 9, 1916 to March 4, 1921. Pancho Villa raided Columbus, New Mexico, killing or wounding 15 Americans (depicted in nearby Bain photos) on Baker's first day in office, an act that Baker considered Villa's test of him, and Baker authorized General Pershing's expedition to capture Villa. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50710F93B5B17738...; en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton_D._Baker His 1937 New York Times obituary: select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F0091FF93A59177A...; His wife was Elizabeth Wells Leopold Baker. His son was Newton D. Baker III. One of his daughters was Elizabeth Baker (Mrs. John Phillips) McGean of Cleveland, the other was Margaret Baker (Mrs. Fulton) Wright of St. Louis. www.wvculture.org/history/government/bakernewton01.html ech.case.edu/cgi/article.pl?id=BND

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] In the middle ages, with a few exceptions for dignitaries and the like, if you did not get inside the city gates by sunset you had to stay outside the gates until sunrise. This is where the criminals had been banished. There was no law outside the city gates. You were at their mercy. This kept people in line and made them very punctual about doing business. It was also a good deterrent against committing crimes!
Very cool.

One of the photos in the Bain collection showing women doing man's work during wartime especially in Berlin. Other photos under www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/8903294002/

I highly doubt that this is a police woman, Germany didn't get police women till the 1920s.
Furthermore she seems to be holding a ticket clipper and might be standing in a tram.
I think she is a tram conductor.
Was she called a police woman on the original photo or more recently?
She has a badge with the inscription "Bahn Polizei Beamter" (railway police official).
Of course, I could not see that on the copy I was looking at, silly me.

the badge says "Bahn Polizei", however, the lady in question was employed as ticket controller at one of the regular railway or city railway (U-Bahn or S-Bahn) stations in Berlin. In her hand she´s holding a ticket slip puncher and she is effectively blocking the passage to or out of the platform. Women were, indeed, employed, by the Reichsbahn but not by the police s such. Hope that helps. Greetings from Berlin!
Original is inscribed "policewoman," but we can add a note of nuance to the record.  Thanks, All!

I originally thought this would be: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abdul_Hamid_II "Abdulhamid II (Ottoman Turkish: عبد الحميد ثانی `Abdü’l-Ḥamīd-i sânî, Turkish: İkinci Abdülhamit) (22 September 1842 – 10 February 1918) was the 99th caliph of Islam and the 34th sultan of the Ottoman Empire. He was the last Sultan to exert effective control over the Ottoman Empire. He oversaw a period of decline in the power and extent of the Empire, ruling from 31 August 1876 until he was deposed on 27 April 1909. He was succeeded by Mehmed V. His deposition following the Young Turk Revolution was hailed by most Ottoman citizens, who welcomed the return to constitutional rule]" But B-59 corrected me.

It's rather Mehmed V Reshad (Ottoman Turkish: محمد خامس Meḥmed-i ẖâmis, Turkish: Mehmed V Reşad or Reşat Mehmet) (2/3 November 1844 – 3/4 July 1918), 35th Ottoman Sultan and successor of Abdul Hamid II IMO. His reign lasted from 27 April 1909 to 3 July 1918. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mehmed_V See also madmonarchist.blogspot.ch/2010/04/monarch-profile-sultan-...
According to tipsimages.it/Photo/ShowImage_Editorial_Popup.asp?IMID=29..., this photo is from 1915. Similar photo without uniform: tipsimages.it/Photo/ShowImage_Editorial_Popup.asp?IMID=14...
@B-59; You are right.  I'll modify my earlier comment.
swanq and B-59:  Thanks for your sleuthing here.  We will include the Sultan's name with the description next time we update.

In Oct 1913, a Lucille Singleton, who claimed to to be the 19-yr-old daughter of a Texan mine owner, was involved in a bizarre incident in which her companion (who appears to have given a false name) stabbed her in a jealous rage and crashed the car he was driving -- and in which she was a passenger!! See The Ogden standard., October 02, 1913, 4 o'clock p.m. City Edition, Page 5, Col 1. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058396/1913-10-02/ed-... The NYT of October 4, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0611F73A5F13738... indicated that charges would be dropped. She admitted to being drunk.

www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=48771988 is the grave of Colonel Lewis M. Koehler, retired cavalry colonel.

El Paso herald., April 24, 1915, HOME EDITION, Cable News and Classified Section, Page 3-B, Image 11, top of col 2. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88084272/1915-04-24/ed-... gives him the rank of Lieut.-Col. among those at a dinner at Fort Bliss, in El Paso, Texas. A couple of months earlier he was a major. El Paso herald., February 23, 1915, HOME EDITION, Page 5, top of col 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88084272/1915-02-23/ed-... El Paso herald., February 21, 1916, HOME EDITION, Page 14, col 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88084272/1916-02-21/ed-... reports that Lt-Col Koehler was granted a 30-day leave of absence.

According to the NYT, March 23, 1907 he was court-martialed in 1907. The sun., March 12, 1914, Page 14 col. 6 reported that in 1914 his brother Benjamin M. Koehler was court-martialed as well. The case of Lewis Koehler is also mentioned in that article.

A description of his career (with photo) is in the Fifthy-seventh Annual Report of the Association of Graduates of the United States Military Academy, West Point 1926 (digital-library.usma.edu/libmedia/archives/aogreports/V19...), pages 101f. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_J._Hill "James Jerome Hill (September 16, 1838 – May 29, 1916), was a Canadian-American railroad executive. He was the chief executive officer of a family of lines headed by the Great Northern Railway, which served a substantial area of the Upper Midwest, the northern Great Plains, and Pacific Northwest. NYT of February 3, 1916 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40F13F6355C1373... reports on Zeppelin raids in eastern England the previous Monday. The article mentions a bomb dropping near a "mission room" in Staffordshire.
Apparently the mission was a Congregational chapel and four people were killed.  At least one inquest on the casualties brought in a verdict of "Wilful murder by the Kaiser."

Arthur von Briesen (1843-1920), a New York City lawyer and philanthropist. Von Briesen, a German-American patent lawyer, served as President of the Legal Aid Society of New York (1889-1916), and as president of the Alliance of Legal Aid Societies of America. (findingaids.princeton.edu/collections/MC034) The site of Von Briesen Park, Staten Island was the former estate of Arthur von Briesen. (www.5borohistory.com/2012/11/shore-acres-staten-island.html)

S.F.B. Morse is presumably www.nyu.edu/greyart/information/Samuel_F_B__Morse/body_sa... "Better known as the inventor of the electric telegraph, Samuel F. B. Morse was also a professor of painting and sculpture at New York University, which was founded in 1832. His appointment that year to the first such professorship in the United States represents a milestone in his mission to promote the fine arts as truly American. " Corbis has a photo of the portrait in color www.corbisimages.com/stock-photo/rights-managed/MA01644A/...

From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Morse#Painting "Morse was honored to paint the Marquis de Lafayette, the leading French supporter of the American Revolution. He felt compelled to paint a grand portrait of the man who helped to establish a free and independent America. In his image, he enshrouds Lafayette with a magnificent sunset. He has positioned Lafayette to the right of three pedestals: one has a bust of Benjamin Franklin, another of George Washington, and the third seems reserved for Lafayette. A peaceful woodland landscape below him symbolized American tranquility and prosperity as it approached the age of fifty. The developing friendship between Morse and Lafayette, and their discussions of the Revolutionary War, affected the artist after his return to New York City." inventors.about.com/od/mstartinventors/a/samuel_morse.htm indicates that the portrait was commissioned by New York City. www.nyc.gov/html/artcom/html/tours/visit_guide_collection... indicates that it hangs in City Hall in New York. NYT of February 10, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F5061FFB3E5E13738... suggests that Quigg's activities in relation to the Interborough Rapid Transit Company were under investigtion by the Thompson Committee. See comments with

Quigg testified on February 25, 1916 (proceedings commenced, p. 871), at the Joint Legislative Committee Investigation of Public Service Commissions (Thompson Committee), at the New York County Lawyers Association Boardroom at 165 Broadway, New York. His testimony (and this picture) reflect that he was angry to be called and impatient to be finished. When Senator Thompson suggested that the photographers should take pictures, there was the following exchange, which reminds one how much smoke was generated by the photographic flash units of the day: (Photographs taken) Chairman Thompson: We will suspend now and if Mr Quigg will consent we will have pictures taken. Mr Quigg: I wish you would finish that, Mr Chairman, if it has got to be done. Mr Moss: Mr Chairman unless you have some- Chairman Thompson: It makes a lot of smoke in here and I would like to have it done with. Mr Moss: Mr Chairman, any question ? Chairman Thompson: One more photograph I am told and then we will get this smoke out of here. (Recess while windows are opened) books.google.com/books?id=ZKc3AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA928&d...

According to Honolulu star-bulletin., February 17, 1916, 3:30 Edition, SPORTS, CLASSIFIED AND SHIPPING SECTION, Page THIRTEEN "DAME RUMOR NAMES - TAD JONES AS COACH" it was "also understood that M. F. Sweeney, an instructor in physical culture at Hill School and a former well known athlete at St Francis Xaviers college, is to be called as a consulting coach." (of the Yale football team).

Yes. Michael F. Sweeney, for 15 years athletic director at Hill School, Pottstown, Pa., was appointed general adviser in all athletics at Yale on Feb. 3, 1916. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0D10F6355C13738... This same picture accompanies a biographical sketch on the Hill School site's "Founders Hall of Fame". "Mike Sweeney was hired in 1896 to develop an athletic program that would involve every student, effectively making him the first Athletic Director in school history. His program became well known and was copied by many other schools. Yale University tried to hire him away, but he remained loyal to Hill, though the School did gave him a year off to go and set up a similar program at Yale. When Mike came to The Hill, he was well known for track, as he was the holder of the world record for the running high jump at the time. Many students came to The Hill just to be coached by Mike Sweeney. Also, many nearby track stars would come to The Hill workouts just to gain from Mike's instruction. He developed many athletes who continued running in college and also several Olympic runners. Mike also made a name for himself as a football coach. When Mike Sweeney came to The Hill he knew nothing about football. He studied the game from the time he was hired until the time he began his Hill School career, and it did not take long for him to establish a successful program. In his approximately 15 years of coaching football, seven of his teams finished undefeated, and two of them were un-scored upon. Sweeney Gymnasium was built in his honor while he was still a member of the faculty." www.thehill.org/RelId/1107422/ISvars/default/Page_3.htm

This building, also known as Palazzo Corpi, housed U.S. diplomatic missions from 1882 to 2003, when the embassy was moved to a new building for security reasons. The addition on the back, known as the Chancery, was built in 1910. "Albert Ballin (15 August 1857 – 9 November 1918) was a German businessman, who was the general director of the Hamburg America Line, at times the world's largest shipping company. Facing the loss of his company's ships, Ballin committed suicide by taking an overdose of sleeping pills in 1918 two days before the end of World War I. Ballin is the father of modern cruise ship travel." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Ballin

He was in the news in February, 1916 when the contents of an interview (attributed to Ballin) with a Bremen newspaper was published. In it, he warned, presciently, of the short and long term effects of a breach in U.S.-German relations. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E11FB3B5B1773...

This fountain was created for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition in San Francisco. This is a detail of the rear center portion of the fountain. From a contemporary account: "The Fountain of El Dorado, by Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, tells the story of an Aztec myth of a god whose brilliance is so dazzling that the sun is his veil, and who lives in a darkened temple lest his light destroy humanity. (p. 54.) At the center of the recessed wall are doors of the deity's shaded abode, a guardian on either side. In the friezes naked humanity moves ever onward, striving to reach the home of the god. The figures, in full relief, are splendid in their grace and vigor. Here are men and women whom nothing can hold back; here are those who must be pushed along, some who linger for love, others for worldly goods; but all, the strong and the faint, the eager and the tardy, move forward irresistibly to their destiny." www.books-about-california.com/Pages/The_Jewel_City/The_J... www.books-about-california.com/Pages/The_Jewel_City/Illus... The complete fountain; cdn.calisphere.org/data/13030/tt/tf2k4007tt/files/tf2k400... According to many sources, the fountain ended up in Lima, Peru. I can only find reference to a different Whitney fountain, with three nude figures holding up something, in Lima.
Elsewhere in LOC's Flickr Commons postings, Ms. Whitney's fountain in the lobby of the Organization of American States building in Washington D.C. Then known as the Pan American Building.

Gertrude V. Whitney had won a competition to design the memorial to victims of the sinking of the Titanic, a memorial eventually completed in 1931 in Washington, D.C. This and the following picture are her models for the memorial. www.dcmemorials.com/index_indiv0001104.htm en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Titanic_Memorial_(Washington,_D.C.) video re history of monument, which was moved in the 60's to make way for the Kennedy Center: www.c-spanvideo.org/program/310623-1

Sculpture by Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney (1875-1942): "Gertrude had always had a passion for art, but had never acted on that passion. During a trip to Europe in 1901, and the resultant exposure to European art museums, reactivated Gertrude’s passion for art. She was particularly interested in sculpture, studied art, and became a sculptress herself. Soon thereafter she became a patron of the arts, promoted the advancement of women in the arts, and organized exhibitions for promising artists. The fountain in the patio of the Pan American building in Washington, D. C. is one of Gertrude’s best known sculptures. Gertrude’s major and lasting accomplishment of her life was the founding of the Whitney Museum for American Art in 1930. Together with her husband Harry P. Whitney they made a major gift that made it possible for the Whitney Museum of American Art to be established." www.newnetherlandinstitute.org/history-and-heritage/dutch... See notes under

William Crapo "Billy" Durant (December 8, 1861 – March 18, 1947) was a leading pioneer of the United States automobile industry, who created the system of multi-brand holding companies with different lines of cars; and the co-founder, with Frederic L. Smith, of General Motors, and of Chevrolet with Louis Chevrolet.  Source: Wikipedia
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_C._Durant

For auto industry context, see www.nytimes.com/1986/01/26/automobiles/some-milestones-of... 1916 saw the Federal Road Aid act, providing states with highway funds. Durant was in the news a lot in early 1916 as stockholders and management of Chevrolet and General Motors tussled for control. In June 1916, he was elected president of General Motors. See NYT of June 2, 1916 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00A14F63D5F1373... "DURANT SUCCEEDS NASH.; Head of Chevrolet Co. Elected President of General Motors."

Baron George von dem Bussche-Haddenhausen (1869–1923).

German diplomat. See for example, NYT of Dec 1, 1903, when he was First Secretary of the German Embassy in Washington. See also NYT of December 25, 1916 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50A16FD3E5F1373... "OFFICIAL GERMANY SPEAKS; Sympathetic to Wilson's Note, Under Secretary Bussche Says."
His wife:

This is not Baron Georg von dem Bussche-Haddenhausen (1869–1923) IMO. A photo of him and his wife is in Evening star., October 31, 1903, Page 5, see also comment under the photo of his wife. He was first secretary and counselor of the German embassy and left the USA in 1906 to be counselor of the department of foreign affairs in Berlin (Evening star., May 21, 1906, Page 5, 5. column)

It's Hilmar Freiherr von dem Bussche-Haddenhausen (* January 31, 1867 in Hannover; † November 19, 1939 in Ramos Mejia, Argentina) (de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilmar_von_dem_Bussche-Haddenhausen, in German) He was described as "the handsomest man In the diplomatic corps, and his wife one of the most attractive women in the same circle. ... He is the son of the late master of the horse to the Duke of Brunswick, and a member of one of the most ancient and distinguished families of Hanover." (The times dispatch., March 13, 1904, Image 19, col. 1) They had a daughter named Matilda, a photo of her is in the Amador ledger., March 23, 1906, Image 6, with description in column 1 "From the Antipodes".

@B-59: Agreed. According to www.wikitree.com/wiki/Von_dem_Bussche-Haddenhausen-7 Hilmar (born 1867) and Georg (born 1869) were brothers. I believe my comments/links for the "diplomat" above are in fact for Hilmar, since no first name is given.

www.theodorerooseveltcenter.org/Research/Digital-Library/... is a letter from Herbert H. D. Peirce to Hilmar. At least the Theodore Roosevelt Center recognizes the diplomat in the US in 1903 as Hilmar.
Thanks, all.  We'll add "Hilmar" to the record.

Family of Japan's Foreign Minister Baron Ishii?

Quite likely yes, another photograph in the New-York tribune., August 17, 1919, Page 5 (unfortunately not in very good quality) shows the children of Viscount Ishii Kikujirō, at that time ambassador to the United States, receiving a letter from their daddy.

Another Bain photo in the LOC collection, Ishii with wife and daughter: www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ggb2006000569/ However, the wife and daughter in this undated image is part of an apparent composite photo, credited to Underwood and Underwood, which ran in the February 19, 1918 Rochester Democrat Chronicle. That means the girl in the photo above is either a different Ishii daughter or the photo is much earlier than 1918. fultonhistory.com/Process%20Small/Newspapers/Rochester%20... And here is a photo which was published about the same time, showing the Ishiis with a small daughter: fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%209/New%20York%20NY%20Sun/New...

This fits, the wife (at right in the Bain photo) and the small daughter are obviously the same as in the photo depicted in the Sun, April 21, 1918. The other woman in the Bain photo is the older daughter IMO.
B-59 and artolog: Thanks for the additional research on this photo, which will let us better identify the family depicted.

The (Portland) Sunday Oregonian ran this photo, credited to Bain, on March 16, 1916, with the following caption: "The firemen of Tokio give exhibitions on festival days near the Shinobizu pond. It is rather different from the wall-climbing and rescue work of our own fire laddies. But, while its practical value in conquering flames does not appear, it is undoubtedly splendid training for the men." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-03-19/ed-1/se... The location is probably misspelled and is Shinobazo pond, a very large pond in Tokyo's Ueno Park. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinobazu_Pond See also

There is a similar photo in The Pickens sentinel., December 28, 1916, Image 2. The men on the ladders are exactly in the same pose, but the perspective is slighty different and the photographers in the foreground are missing.

Charles Franklin Niles, early aviator who was famous for stunt flying. He died in a crash landing in June, 1916. A photo of him shaking hands in Tokyo was published in the New York Sun on February 6, 1916 with the following caption: "CHARLES F. NILES. NOW FLYING IN JAPAN. SHAKES HANDS WITH A PRINCE. CHARLES F. NILES. the looplng aviator from Rochester. N. Y.. has lately been drawing crowds of 250,000 persons to witness his startling exhibition flights In Tokyo, Japan. After Lincoln Beachey was killed Niles took his place as chief trick flier at the Panama-Pacific Exposition. He went to Japan when the exposition closed. He expects to fly in China and India before returning to New York to give exhibition flights here next summer. No other aviator has ever had such a reception as was accorded Niles in Tokyo on the day of his first flight, according to the Japan Times of Tokyo. Among those who congratulated him after the flight were Prince Higashi Kuni, Gen. Nagaoka, president of the Aero Club of Japan, and G. W. Guthrie. the American Ambassador.Gen. Nagaoka said that the Japanese were grateful to Commodore Perry, for it was due to him that Western Ideas had been introduced Into Japan; but that they would be just as grateful to Niles for having shown them the wonderful possibilities of aviation. Niles is known among his friends as "Do Anything." He made his first successful loop on April 18, 1914, at Hempstead. L. I. " fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%209/New%20York%20NY%20Sun/New... This account places the event on December 11th and 12th at the Meiji Shrine Outer Garden [then the Aoyama Parade Grounds], and identifies the biplane as a Curtiss. books.google.com/books?ei=4459Us6BDNOgkAeAoIDgAg&id=i... Another biographical sketch, with clippings and further information: looking-for-mabel.webs.com/5aviators.htm#707707551 More information in this monograph on Aviation in Rochester, starting at p. 299: earlyaviators.com/shafer.pdf another shot of the event: Niles was well known in New York, having flown upside down over Lower Broadway in June, 1914. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2018/New%20York%20NY%20Press/...

Here is a detailed firsthand account of Niles' exhibition: AMERICAN AVIATOR'S TRICKS THROUGH JAPANESE EYES By TOHA HACHINO I AM greatly pleased to have this opportunity to report to the American public what a glorious success in aviation was attained by Mr Charles Niles on December 11 and 12 in parade ground Aoyama Tokyo to the indescribable amazement of 300,000 of Japanese spectators who have never expected or thought possible anything like such dangerous performances in such a tremendous height on such a frail and obstinate machine. Before reporting what impression it made on the Japanese public let me give a rough sketch of the actual scenes on the occasion. Numberless rows of chairs for the spectators were set along the enclosure of the immense parade ground which was at the same time decorated with innumerable flags representing different nationalities. The exit of the aeroplanes from the shelter was welcomed by the melodious musical performance of the military band. At 2 o'clock His Imperial Highness Prince Higashi Kuni put in an appearance and was saluted by Lieutenant General Nagaoka and Mr Jagawa MP who were respectively appointed to be the president and vice president of the committee hastily created for welcoming Mr Niles. Hundreds of naval and military officers interested in aviation also attended the occasion. In the meantime Mr Niles appeared amid cheering of spectators on the scene in a plain aviation suit apparently cheerful and light hearted but composed and self collected. His manners indicated the great confidence he seemed to place in his capability to conquer any hostile air current that he may meet in the Japanese skies. A brief examination of the machine having been completed he jumped on Bleriot monoplane which immediately made a steep ascent such as has never been seen in Japan after running about 10 meters on the ground. He first drew a large semi circle along the enclosure of ground over the heads of the spectators then from the height of about 500 meters he dashed downward halting on the ground with remarkable agility and lightness. At 2:40 he swung up again and then after making several rounds at the height of about 1,000 meters accomplished various dangerous feats with wonderful success among which somersaults backward and forward and sidewise were most amazing. Of all the attracting sights that I have seen in the past none surpassed in boldness and manliness and faultlessness what was displayed by Mr Niles. The same must have been the case with all other spectators Their cheers applause literally "shook the pillars of the firmament and the axis of the earth" a familiar Japanese expression. For a moment they lost themselves in ecstasy of admiration over the incredible wonders they have for the first time seen displayed by an American. One and all as if by previous arrangement shook their hats crying out like people who have gone crazy. After about 10 minutes of successive performances Mr Niles made an almost perpendicular dive from an altitude of about 200 meters directly toward the tent in which was Prince Kuni exactly as if it were falling down. Every spectator held his breath with profound anxiety but soon breathed a sigh of relief when the machine suddenly changed its direction at a point about 10 meters high from the ground and safely landed. Mr Niles came down with a smiling expression walked towards Prince Kuni with whom he had the honor of shaking hands (a remarkable event in Japan for a blood prince to shake hand with professional aviators). The prince uttered every eulogy imaginable and gave Mr Niles a wreath as the token of his boundless admiration. The second flight on a Curtis biplane was accomplished with a still greater success overwhelming the populace with infinite amazement . The name of Mr Niles is now echoing and re-echoing throughout the whole Tokyo. Japanese have been stunned with astonishment to see such an impossible thing as the somersault of the aeroplane actually practised before their eyes which were accustomed only to the elementary display of Japanese aviators. They are now ready to admit that in the degree of proficiency attained Mr Niles is as superior to the Oriental aviators as a peak of Alps is to the top of the Tour Eifel in Paris. In fact when Mr Niles mounted on the machine it appeared suddenly enlivened with soul. There was no more of the senseless obstinate machine with which Oriental aviators have much trouble to deal. In the course of the several dangerous feats there was absolutely no impression of the plane being under the artificial control of the rider but it appeared like a veritable bird flying on its own accord, up and down, right and left, setting at scornful defiance the caprice of the elements much dreaded by the Oriental aviators. All the Tokyo papers agree in lavishing admiration and eulogy on the wonderful achievements of Mr Niles. Some commenced a long statement under the big heading of "The Magic of the Air." Some remarked that even birds would feel abashed at it. Some described the plane as a fan tossed up in the mid air. Again another began its sensational article by saying that the sky of Tokyo was conquered by an American aviator. Moreover the intelligent public are one in acknowledging the great service Mr Niles has indirectly rendered to the cause of aviation in Japan. He has shown by his extraordinary dexterity what a wide area is still left for the Japanese aviators to cultivate and that it is possible for human beings to vie with winged creatures in the air by dint of strenuous exertion. He has also impressed upon the Japanese that aviation is not necessarily a very risky and dangerous business if attended with sufficient skill and proper attention. High officers of the navy and the army who were present on the occasion were one and all extremely pleased to have such brilliant examples shown before the young officers, for one actual instance is better than a hundred oral encouragements. Japanese are by their nature vehement in the spirit of rivalry. When they have an act of superiority shown by others they cannot coolly suffer to let them go as permanently superior. They are ready to tax their capabilities to the utmost even at the cost of their lives to accomplish what they once determined to attain. And in this light Mr Niles' visit to Japan will be sure to mark a new era in the history of the Japanese aviation just as she was awakened to a new national life by the call of Commodore Perry on the door of her exclusiveism of 300 years. In conclusion I should like to note with what an open hearted friendship the Japanese public welcomed the arrival of Mr Niles in Tokyo. I am sure even the hardest hearted anti-Japanese Americans would be ashamed to talk of the Japanese expulsion any more if only they personally witnessed it. books.google.com/books?id=V3fmAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22charles%...

There is a photo of a destroyed bridge over the Morava in The Madison journal., February 19, 1916, Image 3, but it's unclear if it's the same bridge and where it is. And I found another photo of a wrecked bridge over the Morava in the Internet. There are significant similarities between the bridges, but it's obviously another bridge (besides of that, I couldn't find a village named "Praskovze"). I found several bridges, especially over the West-Morava, which could be the bridge in the Bain photo, it's perhaps the bridge at Jasika, near Krusevac (www.panoramio.com/photo/6691897) or the bridge at Trstenik (www.panoramio.com/photo/88420878).

This photo appeared in Hardware World for April, 1916, in an article about Ada Schilling with the title "Lack of Physical Strength No Obstacle to Feminine Achievement". According to the article, she was 4'11" and weighed 95 pounds. She had been trap shooting for 3 years and had many trophies, including "lady championship of California and the Pacific Coast." books.google.com/books?id=pC86AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA96&lp... In this 1917 newspaper article, she encouraged other women to take up the sport, and is also identified as being from Portland, Oregon: news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19170623&... This 1919 article says she had relocated to Portland from San Jose, California and was married to another professional shooter, Carl Schilling. oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1918-11-03/ed-1/se... In 1911, Carl and Ada had a sharpshooting theatrical act that involved such feats as lighting a match with one shot and putting it out with the next. www.library.illinois.edu/dnc/Default/Skins/APE/Client.asp... The San Francisco Call ran a profusely illustrated article about the Schillings and their shooting prowess, including a photo of the diminutive Ada shooting while being held across her husband's arms: cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19090711.2.165.7#
Actually a shotgun.

The woman on this photo is not Mrs. Rutherford Stuyvesant, it's May Palmer Depew, the wife of Chauncey M. Depew (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chauncey_Depew). As I searched for photos of Mrs. Rutherford Stuyvesant in the newspapers, I found one (in The Salt Lake tribune., July 20, 1913, Second News Section, Image 13), but it has not much similarity, but another photo on the same page has: this of Mrs. Depew, with the same hair jewelry. The same photos are in The Washington herald., July 20, 1913, Page 5. Other photos of May Palmer Depew, e.g. in The San Francisco call., March 16, 1902, Image 3 prove that not the newspapers mixed up the photos, but the Bain agency. I presume that this photo was taken long before 1915. There are other Bain photos of Mrs. Depew which had been taken later, p.e. see also comments there Other comments are on

I think this should be Marjorie STERRETT, the 13-year-old Brooklyn girl who wrote a letter to the Navy Department in February, 1916 that resulted in the founding of a fund to give prizes for battleship preparedness that is awarded to this day. See: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60A15FF345C13738... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marjorie_Sterrett_Battleship_Fund_A... I think this photo and the following ones of Teddy Roosevelt, may have been taken at the same event. Roosevelt was actively campaigning for he US to enter the World War in 1916, and Marjorie's offer to contribute her weekly 10 cent allowance towards the building of a dreadnaught, would have made a great PR opportunity for TR. The New York Times reports that TR met with Marjorie Sterrett on board the SS Guiana on February 11, 1916. Roosevelt was on a 5 week trip to the Caribbean for health reasons. According to the Times, Teddy greeted Marjorie with, "Hello Mabel, how do you do? I am glad to meet you and give three cheers for you and your battleship. You are doing great work."
The article about the meeting of TR with Marjorie Sterrett is here: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F50C15FF345C13... Another photo of her: New-York tribune., February 06, 1916, Page 3

I have been unable to identify Marjorie or her family in US Census records at ancestry.com.  The only entry that I have found that is indisputably her is the following:

STERRETT, MARJORIE DEAN; b. 1902, Silver Creek N.Y.; educ. Pub.. schls., Erie Pennsylvania and Phila. ,Pa., and N.Y.C.; screen career, Edison (“Cy Whittaker’s Ward,” “Three Things”); rides, swims, skates, wrestles, boxes; founder of Marjorie Sterrett battleship fundfor children that spread all over the country; rough soubrettes and comedy.  Hght., 5, 1; wght., 126; brown hair, blue eyes. Home address, 28 N. Decatur ave., N. Y. C.
Motion Picture Studio Directory, 1919 at ancestry.com

Language note: A "rough soubrette", according to a biography of Mae West, is "a woman who attempted songs, dances and jokes that were considered the domain of male performers."

After some research and correspondence it appears more than likely that Marjorie Sterrett, of the battleship fund, was born as Marjorie Rockwood Dean in Silver Creek, Chautauqua Co., New York, on May 29th. 1902. Her parents were Fred C. Dean and Grace Rockland, both natives of Erie Co., PA. Around 1911, Grace and Fred Dean separated, and Grace remarried Thomas Garfield Sterrett, a native of Erie who was in the newspaper business. Tom Sterrett was a veteran of the Spanish American War, who had re-enlisted in the US Marine Corps in 1907 and seems to have split his time between New York and Pennsylvania newspaper work and military service. In the Marines he was employed in recruiting efforts in the years before and during the USA’s entry into World War I. He is credited with having a genius for publicity and was responsible for staging public events and placing copy in newspapers in order to increase the repute of the Corps. By 1915, Captain Sterrett was the chief of the Marine Corps’ New York Publicity Bureau on East 24th Street in Manhattan. Various records and newspaper articles give Brooklyn addresses for himself and/or his family, although they are not shown living there in any of the Federal Censuses. In 1916 there was mounting pressure on the non-interventionist Wilson administration to ready the US armed forces for entry into the raging European war. One of the most visible proponents of “preparedness” was former president Theodore Roosevelt. It is against this background that Captain Sterrett’s pretty 13-year-old stepdaughter wrote her moving letter to the New York Tribune offering up her dime allowance to help build a battleship for the Navy. Within a very short amount of time she was standing on the deck of the SS Guiana schmoozing with the ailing Roosevelt who very publicly had embraced Marjorie’s cause and contributed dimes on behalf of his young grandchildren. (I find it curious that Bain didn’t archive a photo of TR and Marjorie together although they each are shown separately on board the ship.) Marjorie’s letter generated a great deal of publicity across the US and bolstered the public acceptance of a pro-war stance. There were deep-seated suspicions that the war was being fought for the benefit of munitions manufacturers and profiteers, and that the US should stay out of Europe’s mess. Marjorie’s act provided a patriotic subtext for the hawks of that day. The fact that her stepfather was a PR man for the armed forces was not discussed in the coverage of the story. Sometime after she burst upon the public scene, Marjorie was invited to make some short films for the Edison Company. Her film career never took off and, rather soon, was living quietly with her parents Thomas and Grace Sterrett back in Erie. Tom Sterrett returned to the newspaper publishing business after the conclusion of the War, and by the late 1920’s had been elected Sherriff of Erie County PA. In 1920, Marjorie (under the name Marjorie Rockwood Dean) was married to Peter Raun in Erie, with whom she had several children. Marjorie died at the age of 24 in Wattsburg, Erie Co. PA on March 2, 1927. See also: oldtimeerie.blogspot.com/2013/11/naval-award-named-for-er...

The Centre Block containing the Parliament building was destroyed by fire on 3 February 1916.
The Centre Block containing the Parliament building was destroyed by fire on 3 February 1916.

I believe this image is held by the Library and Archives Canada under the Item ID number (MIKAN) 3192647. The caption is "Centre Block fire, Parliament Buildings. Photograph taken at 12:30 a.m., a few minutes before the collapse of the tower", Since it is 12:30 a.m., the photograph was taken on February 4, 1916, as the fire ignited in the evening of February 3, 1916. The fire was found at 8:37 p.m., and within twelve hours, the building was completely destroyed, except for the Library of Parliament, spared by the closing of its heavy metal doors. Seven people died in the fire including MP Bowman Brown Law. The tower ignited in the middle of the image was the "Victoria Tower", a 55 metre bell tower completed in 1866. It was replaced with the "Peace Tower" in the new Parliament building, with a new centre block completed in 1920, and peace tower in 1926. The author of the photo is listed as J.B. Reid. Source: Credit: J.B. Reid / Library and Archives Canada / C-010079 (recherche-collection-search.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/home/record...) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_Block ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/the-night-parliament-bu...

Evenson from Iola, Portage County, Wisconsin (according to genforum.genealogy.com/norway/messages/7428.html) "Christian K Ellingsen 12 June 1886 he married Emma Mathilde Evensen (born 23 December 1866 in Iola, Waupaca Co.) in Wausau, Marathon Co., Wis, and they got two children born there: C.K. was for ten years foreman at the Parchers & Stewart sawmill in Scandinavia. In 1890 he and his brother Sam accompanied by nephew C.P. bought a sawmill in Stetsonville, Wis. In 1902 they bought a large area near Hawkins, Wisconsin, and they founded a Jølster congregation there. C.K. was a bankier and landowner and told friends in Norway he could save 40 000 dollars in a good year. " (from digitalarkivet.uib.no/utstilling/eng/utvfam.htm) See also "A letter from one successful emigrant to another" by C.K. Ellingsen (digitalarkivet.uib.no/utstilling/eng/ckelling.htm). The photos of Ellingsen's letter are in digitalarkivet.uib.no/utstilling/eng/ckfoto.htm, the Ellingsen of one of the photos is certainly the same man as in the Bain photo. According to the Oshkosh Daily Northwestern, March 26,1916 he was nominated as delegate to the National Republican Convention, together with Emil Baensch (www.newspapers.com/newspage/16505163/) See also La Crosse Tribune Wednesday, April 05, 1916, page 6, col. 6 "PHILIPP PROBABUY WINS MAJORITY G.O.P. Frank H. Burnside was the primary test pilot for Thomas Brothers Aeroplane Company (predecessor to the Thomas-Morse company). Here, he is posing next to the Thomas D-2 observation aircraft. The identify of this aircraft is confirmed by the photograph in the bottom panel on Page 12 of the March 20, 1916 issue of Aerial Age Weekly (see link). The text accompanying the photo reads: Photograph of Thomas D-2 type military tractor, taken before its speed trials, which resulted in a new American record of ninety-five miles an hour. The compact Thomas 135 H.P. Aeromotor, with which this machine is equipped, makes possible a very neat installation. Attention is called to the single exhaust pipe, which is in the path of the down draft from the descending propeller blade, sweeping the exhaust gases under the fuselage and away from the pilot and passenger. The next photo in the LoC photostream is another photo of the Thomas D-2. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/10477126675/] Another photo of Burnside: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/14583461759/]
Thanks for the information about Burnside and the link to a resource that provides convincing evidence for the identification of the airplane. We'll add information to our description.

Edith Rockefeller McCormick (August 31, 1872 – August 25, 1932), the fourth daughter of John D. Rockefeller and his wife, Laura Spelman. She was a socialite and opera patron. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edith_Rockefeller_McCormick She was the first wife of Harold Fowler McCormick. They married in 1895 and divorced in 1921. (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Fowler_McCormick). Date on photo: 10/3/21 - the photo was obviously made on occasion of the separation from her husband. See e.g. article in The Washington times., October 07, 1921, FINAL HOME EDITION, Page 8, col. 1 & 2. Another photo in The Bismarck tribune., October 26, 1921, Image 1

Todd Protzmann Davis, the author of villaturicum.blogspot.com/2011_04_01_archive.html believes that the picture was taken in the 1900-1910 period. And the dress looks a better fit with that date than 1921 -- which could be a date when the picture was used. The photo shown in the blog post is not damaged like Bain's. He also has a 1921 photo in a dress more typical of that date villaturicum.blogspot.com/2011/05/edith-in-1921.html

The Washington times., March 12, 1908, Last Edition, Page 9 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1908-03-12/ed-... features a cropped version of this picture with a copyright date of 1904 (copyright by H. W. Sierichs, secretary). And I think I can read that same date and attribution at top right of this picture.

Following up on Sierichs, I find The St. Louis Republic. (St. Louis, Mo.), 29 Jan. 1904. Page 3, col 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84020274/1904-01-29/ed-... a report that selected men and women had been approached through letters from H.W. Sierichs to see if they would agree to have photographic portraits made by "leading photographers" for exhibition at the St. Louis World's Fair. Bain seemed to be behind the plan. The piece suggests that the exhibit for portraits of men was not accepted by the Fair organizers. I have not yet managed to confirm whether the exhibit of women's portraits materialized. Since Sierichs (or Bain) paid for the portraits that were taken, it would certainly make sense that he claimed the copyright. I hypothesize that this picture of Edith Rockefeller McCormick was taken as part of this program. There appears to be a photographer's signature followed by Chicago at lower right. LoC has at least one more portrait copyrighted by Sierichs in 1904, of Miss F.A. Kelley www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/cph.3c25752/

Photographer is probably Koehne. emerydanielshistory.blogspot.com/2010_11_01_archive.html has an obituary clipping for William Louis Koehne, a retired Chicago portrait photographer, with studios in Chicago from 1891 to 1955,
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] great sleuthing - the photo was obviously made in 1904 and reused in 1921.
Great sleuthing indeed, swanq.  Thanks to both of you for such extensive research.  We'll add some of the information you've provided to the record the next time we update.

NYT of Dec 23, 1915 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E16FE3B5B1773... mentioned Dr. Luther T. Townsend, formerly a professor at Boston University. Townsend, L. T. (Luther Tracy), 1838-1922 appears to have been a prolific author: onlinebooks.library.upenn.edu/webbin/book/lookupname?key=...

From famousamericans.net/luthertracytownsend/ "TOWNSEND, Luther Tracy, clergyman, born in Orono, Maine, 27 September, 1838. He was graduated at Dartmouth in 1859 and at Andover theological seminary in 1862, and ordained to the ministry of the Methodist Episcopal church. During the civil war he was adjutant of the 16th New Hampshire volunteers, He was professor of exegetical theology in Boston university in 1867-'8 and of historical theology in 1869-'73, and since the last date has occupied the chair of practical theology. Dartmouth gave him the degree of D. D. in 1871. " and from www.library.yale.edu/div/exhibits/Darwin.htm "Luther Tracy Townsend (1838-1922) was professor at Boston Theological Seminary (now Boston University School of Theology). He argued that scientific theories should be held as mere "working hypotheses." To "possess weight" a working hypothesis must receive the assent of all, or nearly all, who are capable of investigating the subject. By the time of the publication of Evolution or creation, the consensus of scientists was hardening against Darwinism in any form. Seizing the opportunity, Townsend applied the rule. Darwin's hypothesis should have no weight except that accorded to other very questionable speculations.'
Thank you for your research swanq. We'll add some of the information to the record the next time we update.

The Day book., October 05, 1916, LAST EDITION, Image 27 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1916-10-05/ed-... indicates that she was one of three women standing for congress in November 1916. The Washington times., August 07, 1916, HOME EDITION, Image 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1916-08-07/ed-... indicates that she was the first woman ever nominated for Congress -- as a Democrat, in Kansas.

The report of the Washington Times that she was nominated as a Democrat was obviously wrong. She was defeated by Rev. H. J. Corwine, see The daily Missourian., August 07, 1916, Image 1, Col. 3 (with correction). According to Bismarck daily tribune., November 05, 1916, Image 16 she was candidate for congress on an independant ticket. According to Hopkinsville Kentuckian., February 19, 1916, Page 5, last column, she was a physician from Topeka, Kansas with a socialist schedule (opposing militarism, national prohibition, nationwide suffrage, mothers' pensions, recall of judges, old age pensions for those who deposit money for this purpose with the government, a national rural credits law for farm tenants, a tariff for revenue, government aid in road building and the construction of public works to control the flood waters of the Missouri and Mississippi Valleys) See also www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=104654

Picture 11 in the sequence at www.adelsongalleries.com/exhibitions/2006-05-09_light-imp... is a drawing of her by Everett Shinn (1876-1953), perhaps in the same outfit: Bonnie Glass, 1915; Pastel on paper; 33 1/2 x 16 inches; Signed lower left: Bonnie Glass by Everett Shinn 1915

Her personal life was clearly as newsworthy as her professional life. The Evening Independent - Dec 13, 1921 news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19211213&i... has a long piece suggesting that her marriage to the wealthy artist Ben Ali Haggin might be on the rocks. It mentions that here first marriage was in 1911, when she eloped with a Harvard student, Graham Glass, Jr. The article covers a foursome, Bonnie, her husband, her former dancing partner, Al Davis, and his wealthy wife, the former Eugenie Kelly. The Ogden standard-examiner., December 31, 1922, The Standard - Examiner Sunday Feature Section, Image 25 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058393/1922-12-31/ed-... a full-page spread headlined, "And What Will Pretty Bonnie Glass Do Now?" This piece indicates that she and her husband had separated and suggests she might marry her former partner, Al Davis.

LoC has plenty of pictures of her as Mrs. Ben Ali Haggin (some in the Bain collection but not yet up on Flickr) www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=ben%20ali%20haggin&st=... One of the Bain photos not yet on Flickr www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ggb2006000776/resource/ is identified in en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Red_Cross_Pageant as of the National Red Cross Pageant, October 1917. The wikipedia page includes a cast list with roles for the entire pageant. Bonnie Glass/Helen Roche/Mrs Ben Ali Haggin appears to have danced the pavane with a former partner Clifton Webb. The pageant was "the brainchild" of her husband.
Auburn Citizen, Oct 12, 1928 fultonhistory.com/newspaper%202/Auburn%20NY%20Citizen/Aub... indicates that she had recently obtained a Mexican divorce from Haggin.

@swanq: Thanks for diving back into Bain so quickly after the U.S. government shutdown ended. 
You've gathered an impressive variety of sources to round out the story of Bonnie Glass' life, and opened new doors to information by connecting her to her two other names. The full-length color sketch by Everett Shinn brings a nice touch of color & attitude into the story. I don't know clothing styles well enough to fully confirm your observation, but the blue outfit in the sketch sure seems similar to the dress in the Bain photo--at least both show buttons along the bottom of the sleeve along with the fur.  Welcome back! -- Helena (LOC)

Albert Herter (1871–1950), American artist and painter (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Herter). According to The San Francisco call., October 23, 1913, Image 9 (with photo) he was a "noted painter of mural decorations".

For pictures of the lovely house built by Albert Herter, see www.flickr.com/search/?w=8623220@N02&q=albert%20herter, including this garden view: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8623220@N02/7801601698] "Près Choisis," Albert Herter house, Georgica Pond, East Hampton, New York. View to house from orange and yellow garden. In Gardens for a Beautiful America (p. 304) Sam Watters describes the house this way: "The artist Albert Herter was an heir to the Herter Brothers furniture fortune. With his wife Adele McGinnis, also an artist and heir, he built a pink stucco villa overlooking a pond flowing out to the Atlantic Ocean. When asked why his house and garden were reminiscent of Sicily, Albert Herter answered, "It is perhaps the sea; and I am sure our three Sicilian workmen are also responsible." The house had color-themed gardens: a blue and white terrace, and this orange-and-yellow court with continuous bloom; tulips and crocus in April, climbing yellow roses in May and June, followed by yellow phlox and orange-yellow Sweet William, dahlias, trumpet vine, and zinnias. A gray fog softened the floral brilliance when Johnston photographed the house in the early fall. She considered it to have the 'loveliest and most consistently developed waterside garden I know in this country.'" For more pictures related to Herter (in costume, later in life, and his artwork and WWI posters), see the Prints & Photographs Online Catalog, www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=Albert+herter&sp=1&amp... --Helena (LOC)

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durazzo "Durrës [aka Durazzo] is the second largest city of Albania located on the central Albanian coast, about 33 km (21 mi) west of the capital Tirana." "During the First World War, the city was occupied by Italy in 1915 and by Austria-Hungary in 1916-1918. It was captured by the Allies in October 1918. Restored to Albanian sovereignty, Durrës became the country's temporary capital between 1918 and March 1920. "

Acording to www.akpool.co.uk/postcards/24155901-postcard-gotha-eisene... this statue was erected Sept 26, 1915. According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Etrich_Taube The Taube was a "pre-World War I monoplane aircraft. It was the first mass-produced military plane in Germany." www.pictorialgems.com/1916-Gotha-Taube-Memorial-To-German... shows this picture printed in the Illustrated War News of February 16, 1916

This plane with the birdlike tail (the name translates to English as "dove") was reportedly responsible for bombings in Paris in October, 1914. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A07E4DA1438E0... A Bain photo of the damage:
It looks like the sort of memorial you could pay to drive a nail into.  See the leading edge of the wing, and the engine.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/sethgaines] That's correct, the memorial is on a list of "Kriegsnagelungen" (war nailings) (with the same postcard as in swanq's comment), see www.munzel-everling.de/download/Kriegsnagelungen_August_2.... Another example of such a memorial was the "Eiserne Hindenburg" in Berlin Tiergarten see comments there
""Kriegsnagelungen".  I never knew of these, thanks.  I wonder if this monument still exists?  I can't find any trace of it.

I'm quite sure that none of these monuments exists anymore at its original place, some are perhaps in a museum now. Despite of the label "eisern" (iron), these monuments were made of wood. The "Eiserne Hindenburg" e.g. was used as firewood after the war (except the head, which burned in WWII, see de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eiserner_Hindenburg, in German).
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nail_Men is another source of information. Intriguing!
Yes, I suppose the idea was that it would become 'iron' from all the patriotic folks putting nails into it.  They are fascinating.  I'm glad to see so many have survived.

One possibility is that she is the wife of Charles Adams Holder. After some hunting, a source I have found with her name is The Lewiston Daily Sun - Jun 30, 1933 news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1928&dat=19330630&..., which indicates that after her death, her husband was to marry the widow of Enrico Caruso. She is named as the former Margaretta Bonsall Taylor of Philadelphia.
A debutante, see The Washington times., December 05, 1915, SUNDAY EVENING EDITION, Page 8, with photo.

The Washington herald. (Washington, D.C.), 12 Dec. 1915, page 18, right-hand column, under Norfolk Navy Yard label chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1915-12-12/ed-... reports that Mr and Mrs. Frederick Barrett had recently attended the marriage of their niece Julia Littell to Lieut. Alexander McCarrell Patch. Her husband is therefore en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Patch but the wikipedia entry does not cover his personal life.

www.geni.com/people/Julia-Patch/6000000015614953496 indicates that Julia Adrienne Patch (Littell) was born in 1893 and that they had a son, Alexander M. Patch III, in 1920. But it provides no other details for her. What could be this photo is in The Day book. (Chicago, Ill.), 06 Aug. 1915. LAST EDITION, Image 23 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1915-08-06/ed-... announces the engagement and indicates that her parents are Col. and Mrs. I.W. Littell.

From NYT of November 22, 1945 (needs subscription) select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60917FA3D5B1073... General McCarrell died of pneumonia on Nov. 21, 1945. She was still alive and they were still married. Their son had died in action in France in 1944. They had a daughter, also called Julia.

Here she is at Findagrave: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=71200732 and her obituary: "Julia Littell, 95, Widow of Gen. Alexander M Patch, who commanded the Americal Division in Guadaicanal and the U.S. 7th Army in Europe in World War II, died in San Antonio, Texas, September 25. Mrs Patch was the daughter of Brig. Gen. I.W. Littell of Elizabeth, N.J. and Julia Barrett Littell of Baltimore. The Littells were stationed on Governor's island when Mrs. Patch met her future husband. She was an alumna of Oaksmere in New York. Mrs. Patch is survived by one daughter, Mrs. Chandler Diehl of San Antonio, and three grandchildren."
We'll fix spelling of her name in title.
Turkish "Beauty".

"William Murray Black (December 8, 1855 – September 24, 1933) was career officer in the United States Army, noted for his ability to organize and train young engineers." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Murray_Black He led the effort to raise the Maine, see en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Maine_Mast_Memorial#Preparing_to_raise_the_Maine This photo is depicted in The Washington herald., March 03, 1918, Page 7
See also comments under

"John Biddle (February 2, 1859 – January 18, 1936) was career United States Army officer who became superintendent of the United States Military Academy." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Biddle_%28United_States_Army_g...

This photo is depicted in The Washington times., October 26, 1917, FINAL EDITION, Page 2 The Ogden standard., November 07, 1917, 4 P.M. CITY EDITION, Page 10 (with photo) confirms that he was appointed assistant chief of the army general staff.

One Princess De Croy is Marie, but the photo at archive.org/stream/warmemories00croyuoft#page/74/mode/2up doesn't look to be an obvious match. But since she was imprisoned by the Germans durng WWI, she might have lost a lot of weight. Another picture of Princess Marie is at www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portrait/mw224514/Princ... I'm inclined to think this picture is not of her.

Another Princess of Croy is Isabella en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Isabella_of_Cro%C3%BF This picture is a better match, but it seems less likely that she was in the news at this time. And fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabelle_de_Cro%C3%BF suggests she would have been known as Archduchess given she was married to Archduke Frederick of Austria.

Yet another possibility is Princess Charles/Karl de Croy. She was Mathilde de Robiano, but would have been Princess De Croy after her marriage (confirmed by the 1946 announcement of her death at cartes-postales.delcampe.net/page/item/id,0199496393,lang...) I have now found www.genroy.fr/croy.htm which suggests there would have been a lot of women at this time who would be Princess De Croy in their own right and a bunch more who were married to a Prince De Croy.

Seems likely to be www.spanamwar.com/BlackWilliam.htm He retired in 1919 as a Major General, but www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=59224614 seems to imply that he was a Colonel in the 1915 timeframe. The Military Engineer has a description of his entire military career at books.google.com/books?id=mCUgAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA25&lp... and that confirms that his promotion to General was in 1916. A full page portrait near the beginning of the volume looks to be the same man, but without his glasses.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porter_Charlton NYT of Jan 27, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E00E5DF1231E733A... indicates that Porter Charlton returned from Naples on the Italian liner America, after serving a brief sentence for the murder of his wife in 1910. He was met by J.W. Johnston of Western Electric, who had apparently arrange for Charlton to sell his story to the newspapers. See earlier picture, which probably is when he was extradited to Italy:

A 1919 passport photo of Charlton is here: In 1919 he is living in Paris and lists his profession as an employee of the US Postal Express Service. In 1922 he working as an agent of the American Graves Registration Service. He took his own life at Bayonne, France on November 24th, 1933.

Probably Brandram Boileau USSHER, Canadian R. E. bishop, born in Dublin, Ireland, 6 August, 1845 (according to famousamericans.net/brandramboileauussher/) According to THE DOCTOR'S WHO'S WHO of 1906 he was in Boston resp. Dedham, Mass. at that time (www.archive.org/stream/doctorswhoswho00mouluoft#page/239/...) The Kansas City journal., July 23, 1897, Page 8, Column 2 "COMMUNION SET MORTGAGED" says that Bishop B. B. Ussher had founded a Christ Reformed Episcopal Church in 1889, which was later disbanded. The Ashland tidings., February 17, 1916, Page 5, column 2 mentions a Bishop B. B. Ussher of Boston. Brandram Boileau Ussher died in 1925, see e.g. archive.org/search.php?query=creator%3A%22Ussher%2C%20Bra...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Mannering "Mary Mannering (April 29, 1876 – January 21, 1953) was an English actress, born in London." "Born Florence Friend, she was the daughter of Richard Friend and Elise Whiting. She was induced by producer Daniel Frohman to come to New York in 1896. In the United States, she began playing as "Mary Mannering" (the maiden name of her father's mother)." NYT of June 2, 1911 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70F15F83F5517738... reports her marriage to Detroit millionaire Frederick E. Wadsworth, head of the Detroit Motor Boat Company and has a fair amount of biographical detail.

In January 1916, they announced that she would returned to the stage and they would move to New York. See NYT of Jan 14 1916 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0716FD3B5B1773... But it's not clear that she did make a successful comeback. She lived until 1953. NYT of Jan 22, 1953 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0716FD3B5B1773... carries her obituary. Frederick had died in 1927. Nothing of a post-1911 career is mentioned. Also nothing after 1911 in her IBDB entry ibdb.com/person.php?id=51256

Drawing a blank on this pretty young woman. Trying some spelling variants, my only possible clue is in The evening world., July 14, 1922, Wall Street Final Edition, Page 9, top of col 2. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1922-07-14/ed-... under the headline, THREE CHILDREN NEARLY KILLED BY GLASS PUT IN FOOD "The boys are Benny Edgerton, seven: Reed Wolfert, five, and Gregory Kelnlnger, one, grandsons of Mrs. Charles M. Edgerton, Brlggs and Hawtree Avenues. Benny Is the son of D. M, Edgerton. Reed Is the son of F. W. Wolfert and grandson of former State Senator Wolfert of Brooklyn. Gregory Is the baby son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Kienlnger." No mention of Reed's mother, but presumably she was an Edgerton. Following that path, I found boards.ancestry.com/localities.northam.usa.states.newyork... which says "I understand from my father that my Florence edgerton's father was a Charles M. Edgerton. My florence married Frederick Wolfert, however, my father fredericks son was brought up by his grandmother harriet. Florence seems to have disappeared from the family ..." So this could be the former Florence Edgerton -- but I wouldn't bet on it.

www.hallofgovernors.ny.gov/JohnDix38th "John Alden Dix (1860–1928) was the Democratic Party chairman when he successfully sought the governorship in 1910. As governor, Dix created the State Conservation Commission, approved legislation authorizing direct primary elections, and improved state highways. Following the deadly Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire of 1911, Dix helped pass the “one-day-of-rest-in-seven” law that limited the number of working hours for women and children and improved working conditions in factories."
The Political Graveyard politicalgraveyard.com/bio/diperna-dix.html names his wife as Gertrude Thomson. More details on her at www.sackettfamily.info/tekdatabase/g36/p36176.htm
swanq:  Thanks for the additional information here.  We will include some of it next time we update.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consuelo_Vanderbilt "Consuelo Balsan (formerly, Consuelo, Duchess of Marlborough; nee Vanderbilt) (2 March 1877 – 6 December 1964), was a member of the prominent American Vanderbilt family. Her marriage to Charles Spencer-Churchill, 9th Duke of Marlborough became an international emblem of the socially advantageous, but loveless, marriages common during the Gilded Age."

One of the pictures on the Wikipedia page seems to have the same long string of pearls and possibly the same dress. The photo source in Wikimedia is www.persephonebooks.co.uk/the-shuttle.html which, in turn identifies the picture as being from Country House Camera, a book by Christopher Simon Sykes. This suggests a society photographer working on location, but so far I haven't identified the photographer. According to Cash for titles: The Billion-dollar ladies By Daisy Goodwin UPDATED: 14:00 EST, 14 August 2010 www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-1302195/Cash-titles-... a long string of pearls was a wedding gift and once owned by Catherine the Great.
See her elder son and comments at

A 2010 blog post on French Sampler thefrenchsampler.blogspot.com/2010/11/consuelo-vanderbilt... shows a larger photo from which the Bain photo is a crop and the cover of a book about Consuelo and her mother Alva that uses the same photo. Unfortunately, I don't see the photo sources cited. But Goodwin's Weekly : a thinking paper for thinking people. (Salt Lake City, Utah), 23 Dec. 1911, page 36 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/2010218519/1911-12-23/ed-... uses the larger photo (looking more like a studio photograph), credits Underwood & Underwood, and calls it "the latest photograph of the Duchess of Marlborough." If you want to overdose on Consuelo, take a look at www.pinterest.com/larrytenney/consuelo-vanderbilt-1877-1964/. This resource led me to the Goodwin's Weekly piece.

She was frequently in the news for her charitable activities and was an active (but non-violent) supporter of votes for women. The sun., February 07, 1915, FOURTH SECTION PICTORIAL MAGAZINE, Page 8, col 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1915-02-07/ed-... identifies her as chair of a group of "American Women of England" who were organizing war relief efforts, such as opening a hospital for wounded soldiers and sailors. She turned her own Blenheim Palace into a hospital. See, for example, The North Platte semi-weekly tribune. (North Platte, Neb.), 12 March 1915, lower right. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/2010270504/1915-03-12/ed-...
swanq: Thank you for bringing her full identity to our attention here.  We'll include this info. next time we update.

I think this must be en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Spencer-Churchill,_10th_Duke_o... the elder son of the former Consuelo Vanderbilt and the 9th Duke of Marlborough. BTW, I believe his title should be "Marquess" not "Marquis," but the mis-spelling is common. A 1934 portrait is in the UK National Portrait Gallery at www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portraitLarge/mw65606/J...

And www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portrait/mw172279/Consu... is a 1910 portrait of Consuelo with her two sons. The left-hand boy is clearly (if you choose to look at the larger image) the same person a few years younger than this young man. The photo is by Rita Martin and the National Portrait Gallery also has a copy of Country Life with the same photo on the cover.

The sun. (New York [N.Y.]). December 07, 1919, Section 7 Magazine Section, Image 89 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1919-12-07/ed-... features a full page on his engagement under the headline, Britain's Great Matrimonial Catch, Heir to Vanderbilt Millions, Engaged. The photo is clearly of the same young man.

Formerly Grace Carr, „one of the most admired American woman in English high society“, see The San Francisco call., August 03, 1913, Page 24 (with photo). The Evening herald., September 20, 1919, Page 5 (with photo) says that she married William Charles Wynne, Lord Newborough in 1900. Her husband fell in action during WWI. Her husband was then William Charles Wynn, 4th Baron Newborough (1873–1916) (according to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baron_Newborough)
On the other hand, the New-York tribune., December 14, 1919, Page 3 (with photo) says that she was the wife of Thomas John Wynn, that would be the 5th Baron Newborough (1878–1957).

A report about her wedding in The evening world., November 07, 1900, Evening Edition, Page 11, "KENTUCKY BELLE NOW MY LADY NEWBOROUGH" (with photo) names her husband Charles Wynn, so I presume that the article in the New-York Tribune is mistaken.

A blog post, entitled "Las Princesas Dólar" dinastias.forogratis.es/las-princesas-dolar-t3153-204.html has a picture whose caption agrees that Grace Carr's husband was William Charles, 4th Baron and clearly shows the same woman as in this Bain photo. NYT obituary for the 4th Baron on July 20, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60A15FC355B17738... agrees. Lots of ways to express Grace Carr's title are given in the description of a 1928 photo at digital.library.louisville.edu/cdm/ref/collection/heraldp....

www.cracroftspeerage.co.uk/online/content/index495.htm has details for the 4th and 5th barons, who were brothers. Perhaps the 1919 New-York Tribune photo is of a different Lady Newborough. Vera Evelyn Mary Winch, widow of Henry L Winch, dau. of Capt Philip Montagu[e?], of Down Hall, Dorset was the wife of the 5th baron. Although why she should be in the New-York Tribune I can't imagine.
A report about her marriage (with photos) is in El Paso herald., December 10, 1910, Image 10.
Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle, Sr.: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Joseph_Drexel_Biddle,_Sr.. Harry K. Thaw: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Kendall_Thaw

Zach Lamar Cobb, customs collector in El Paso, see El Paso herald., April 03, 1914, HOME EDITION, Image 1, "TERRITORY FOR BANKS SUITS EL PASOANS", with photo. "Zach Lamar Cobb served as the El Paso Collector of Customs from 1913 to 1918--and as an intelligence agent for the United States Department of State during the Mexican Revolution." (from www.amazon.com/Zach-Lamar-Cobb-Intelligence-Southwestern/...) "Zach Lamar Cobb, the US customs collector there, had built a small intelligence network of his own, including railroad employees. These sources reported Huerta's movements, which Cobb relayed to Washington. Cobb also organized the group that arrested Huerta. Once Huerta was arrested, Wilson ordered the Justice Department to detained him and keep him from returning to Mexico, orders the department followed until Huerta's death in custody from complications of alcoholism. (www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/...)
B-59:  Thanks for the link to more information about Cobb. Looks like the same person.  We will include his full name and occupation information in the description next time we update.
