James H. Preston, also known as John H. Preston, (1860-1938), served in the Maryland House of Delegates from 1890-1894. He was Mayor of Baltimore for two terms from 1911-1919. He was defeated when seeking a third term in 1919, and resumed the practice of law. Preston graduated from the Law School of the University of Maryland in 1881 with an LL.B. degree. In 1894 he married Miss Helen Fiske Jackson (b.1874), the daughter of Wilbur Fiske Jackson (1849-1903), and niece of Governor Elihu E. Jackson (1837-1907). They had two sons and three daughters. Mayor Preston was in the national news throughout 1914 as he was the president of the centennial commission directing impressive ceremonies as the people of the United States observed the 100th anniversary of the birth of the immortal anthem, "The Star-Spangled Banner." From July 8 to August 1, 1914, Commission President Mayor Preston toured dozens of major American cities by rail on a good will, centennial promotional tour. President Wilson and former Presidents Taft and Roosevelt, vice presidents, former Governors of Maryland, the former Mayors of Baltimore along with the present Governors of the eighteen states in the union when Francis Scott Key wrote his national anthem, attended the ceremonies at Fort McHenry in Baltimore, September 6-13, 1914. 6,500 public school children formed a human flag on a special platform built for the occasion, followed by singing of the National Anthem accompanied by a 250 piece marching band. For the rest of their lives many of those children would self-describe themselves as "I was a red stripe" or "I was a white star" as they proudly told of their experience to others. The Official Programme for the National Star-Spangled Banner Centennial was 165 pages.   —Compiled: [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8] [9]   There is another photo of James Preston as a younger man in the Bain Collection of the LOC on Flickr:
wonderful excellent potrait

Miss Florence Emily Gilbert (b.1896) and Miss Kathryn (Kitty) Bache (1896–1979), performed in the suffrage opera, "Melinda and Her Sisters", by Mrs. O.H.P. (Alva) Belmont (1853-1933) and Miss Elsa Maxwell (1883-1963), in which society appeared to satirize society. Miss Gilbert performed in "Love Letters" and "The Castle Dancers", and Miss Bache performed in "Love Letters", Sporting Sister", "Hello Song" and "Suffrage Parade". The opera was performed February 18, 1916, in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf Astoria Hotel in New York City. Miss Florence Gilbert, a débutante daughter of Mrs. Cyril (Lilla Brokaw) Dugmore (1870-1939), and her first husband, the late Harry Bramhall Gilbert (1861-1911), was introduced to society in January, 1916, at a tea and dance for 1,000 at Sherry's. She married Sergeant Russell Evans Tucker, Jr., O.R.C. in 1918. As an aside, Florence Gilbert was a bridesmaid and Russell Tucker, Jr., an usher, at the wedding of Mary Duke and Anthony Biddle in July, 1915. There was no word on who caught the bouquet ;) Miss Kathryn (Kitty) Bache [note correct spelling of first name], the débutante daughter of the Wall Street financier Jules Bache (1861-1944), was introduced to society in January, 1914, at a dance at Sherry's. She married the theatre producer, Gilbert Miller (1884-1969), in Paris, France, in 1927. She was a supporter of American theatre who in 1941 helped found the New York branch of the Escholier Club. Columbia University's Kathryn Bache Miller Theatre was named in her honor. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8] [9]   There is another photograph of Florence Gilbert, and an illustration of Kathryn Bache in the Bain Collection on Flickr:                                                   Miss Florence Emily Gilbert                Miss Kathryn (Kitty) Bache
See also:

"Alice Brady's Skating Cap" is one of several portraits made of the actress Alice Brady over the years by Ira (Ira Lawrence) Hill (1877-1947). "Hill opened a New York studio ca.1905; 'the Cecil Beaton of his time in New York,' he photographed the wealthy and socially prominent in his studio and documented social events around the country. He photographed celebrities such as Helen Hayes and Tallulah Bankhead, and published frequently in magazines. He married a succession of five debutantes." [1] "Hill was the most important theatrical portraitist from 1913 to 1917, and a significant portraitist from 1917 to 1924, yet his aesthetic interests increasingly fixed on fashion. In full-figure images--which supplanted the Gibson Head in his posing in 1912--dress mattered as much as personality." [2]

Helen May Valk Borden sued her millionaire husband Gail Borden for divorce in 1911, in Los Angeles; his money came from a condensed-milk fortune. The divorce was finally granted in 1914. news.google.com/newspapers?id=F5YxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3SAEA... query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50611F63B5517738... Big drama. At some point in the difficult divorce process, Helen placed her daughter Ramona in a New Jersey sanitarium/boarding school, to hide her from Gail; then Gail's people kidnapped Ramona from the sanitarium, or maybe she ran away; either way, she turned up in Boston a few days later: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40713FB3C5B13738... query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60F12F83C5B13738... Alexine Ramona Borden (b. 1896) married in 1916, to Cole Parker, at her maternal grandparents' home: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F50915FE345B17... Gail Borden remarried in January 1916, to Margaret B. Coutaint of Pittsburgh. So this is maybe Margaret rather than Helen.

Approaching 3rd Avenue and 42d street express station ("humped" track to right), opened January 17, 1916. See notes under

Signs in the photo show this was the Chatham Square station. City Hall is not shown, but the tall building at upper right is the 40-story Manhattan Municipal Building, first occupied in 1913. The view is approximately southwest along Park Row. Cowperthwaite & Sons, at center, was a large home furnishings company founded in 1807, and located at 193-205 Park Row in Chatham Square. The sign on its building says "now in its 106th year", dating the picture to not before 1913. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan_Municipal_Building books.google.com/books?id=ZHcxAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA78-IA10&a... This picture was probably taken to illustrate the January 17 1916 opening of an express line at the station (the left hand platform in this picture, with tracks going on an upward grade). select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50811FD3B5B1773... All of these tracks and structures have been demolished.

This is Brigadier-General John C. Speaks (1859-1945) Commander, Second Brigade, Ohio National Guard, and Major Robert D. Palmer, Adjutant-General, Ohio National Guard. The Youngstown Iron Sheet and Tube Company, based in Youngstown, Ohio, was one of the largest steel manufacturers in the world. On January 7, 1916, Sheet and Tube workers at the East Youngstown plant rioted during a strike over working conditions, which resulted in most of the town's business district being burned to the ground. The strike was quickly quelled by the arrival of 2,100 National Guard troops, under the command of Brigadier-General Speaks, but not before three people had died and 125 were injured. The arrival of the National Guard as well as offers of increased wages by the steel companies convinced most of the striking workers to return to their jobs. Within a week of the riots the mills were once again operating near full capacity. This photograph appears to have been taken taken at the Hazelton Railroad Yards on January 13, 1916, as the Fifth Regiment was leaving East Youngstown (later renamed Campbell, Ohio) by train. —Compiled: [1] [2] [3] [4] [5]
Other persons related to the strike: Oscar R. Diser Governor Frank B. Willis and (presumably) T.P. Kearns

In light of the prior photo with figures from the Youngstown, Ohio steel strikes and the National Guard, this is likely Ohio Governor Frank B. Willis, who ordered 3 regiments to Youngstown on January 8, 1916 to deal with the violent situation there. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30916FC3B5B1773... Willis' entry at politicalgraveyard.com: Willis, Frank Bartlett (1871-1928) — also known as Frank B. Willis — of Delaware, Delaware County, Ohio. Born in Lewis Center, Delaware County, Ohio, December 28, 1871. Republican. U.S. Representative from Ohio 8th District, 1911-15; Governor of Ohio, 1915-17; defeated, 1916, 1918; delegate to Republican National Convention from Ohio, 1916, 1920, 1924; U.S. Senator from Ohio, 1921-28; died in office 1928. Died suddenly, from a cerebral hemorrhage, as he was about to give a presidential campaign speech, at Ohio Wesleyan University, Delaware, Delaware County, Ohio, March 30, 1928 (age 56 years, 93 days). Interment at Oak Grove Cemetery, Delaware, Ohio. Relatives: Son of Jay B. Willis and Lavinia Willis (1842-1915); married 1895 to Almira Parmelia Dustin (1873-1956). See also congressional biography — Govtrack.us page — National Governors Association biography — NNDB dossier — Find-A-Grave memorial politicalgraveyard.com/bio/willis.html and see: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_B._Willis

"Frank Buchanan (June 14, 1862 – April 18, 1930) was a Democratic member of the United States House of Representatives from Illinois. He served in Congress for three terms from March 4, 1911 to March 3, 1917" en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Buchanan_%28Illinois_politici...

Buchanan had been indicted in New York in late December, 1915 with 7 others for allegedly plotting to stop munitions from going to the Allies. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40612FE3B5B1773... Among his co-defendants was David Lamar, who was convicted. The jury could not unanimously decide Buchanan's guilt, and it hung as to him and 4 others. I can't find a record that they were re-tried.

The SS Patris was a Greek ocean liner that unsuccessfully attempted to tow the damaged liner SS Thessaloniki in December, 1915. The Patris then took Thessaloniki's passengers to New York and Thessaloniki was scuttled. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald... See also:

She had two children, Hoke Smith Simpson, and Maude Raymur Simpson. Presumably the baby is one of these two people.

The Evening Independent (St. Petersburg, Florida), Jun 15, 1927 news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19270615&i... makes clear that Lucy and her husband had a difficult marriage. Eleftherios Venizelos (1864-1936), Prime Minister of Greece from 1910-1920 (and later again from 1928-1932): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eleftherios_Venizelos This photograph, according to the note scratched into the negative at the bottom, was taken on November 20, 1916.

Over December 1915 and January 1916, Venizelos was in the NYT almost daily over disputes/discussions with King Constantine of Greece over his premiership and strategies for Greece wrt WWI. Example from Jan 5, 1916 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0A15FF3B5B1773... Headline: KING CONSTANTINE TURNS TO VENIZELOS; Ex-Premier Declines to Return to Power at Present -- Greece May Yet Join Allies. His identity was the subject of a question in a quiz intended to assess the familiarity of college students with current affairs and the "European War.". From the headline: "Questions About Men Named Daily in the Newspapers Brought Ludicrous Replies." The students had the most trouble with, "Who is Venizelos?" See NYT of Jan 11, 1916 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40A13FC3B5B1773...

Pianist and organist, based in New York City. I can't find a biographical sketch of her. She is on the New York Times' Zombie List of musicians, with a request for biographical information. She was mentioned in The Times for recitals and other professional appearances up until 1950. theater.nytimes.com/library/cyber/mirapaul/0509mirapaul-z... There is some information at americanjewisharchives.org: "Freid, Sara Sokolsky (Mrs Alexander Freid); b. Korytki, Poland. To US 1916.· Royal Academy of Music, Sorbonne. • Pianist, organist, tchr, NYC; author in field. • See: WWIAJ [Who's Who In American Jewry], 1928, 1938." See also:

It is not even clear wether her name was "Sokolsky-Fried" (which is likelier IMO) or "Sokolsky-Freid" resp. "Sokolsky Fried" / "Sokolksy Freid". There are citations of all versions of the name in books, newspapers etc., but I couldn't find a detailed report either.

Newspapers sometimes spelled it Fried, but the biographical sources seem to be consistent withe Freid for both Sara and her husband Alexander (a musical conductor). This looks like another one where the subject was invited to Bain's office for a portrait:

From the American Jewish Chronicle of Feb 9, 1917, p 442. books.google.com/books?id=1UE6AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA442 "Sara Sokolsky Freid will give her first and organ recital of this season on evening February 12 at the Aeolian Hall. The young organist has recently returned from Germany where she was for a short time held interned as a prisoner of war, her husband being a French citizen. While abroad, she studied with the greatest pianists of Europe and is now a musician of the highest rank. Sara Sokolsky Freid is one of the few women organists in the country. Her performances on this instrument have won praise from the highest authorities. The recital on Monday evening promises to be a real musical treat which will live long in the memory of those who will hear it."

Caption is erroneously permuted, should be "E. Youngstown -- Vigilantes under Oscar Diser, City Solicitor" In 1914, Oscar R. Diser of Youngstown (Ohio) was a State Representative and republican candidate for Congress, see The Mahoning dispatch., August 07, 1914, Image 4, with photo. He didn't win the election. in 1916 he formed a committee of safety and helped stop the rioting in East Youngtown (according to The Mahoning dispatch., January 21, 1916, Image 4, column 4). The Mahoning dispatch., January 07, 1916, Image 6 reported that attorney Oscar E. Diser had been elected solicitor of East Youngstown by the council of that municipality. news.nnyln.net/tupper-lake/tupper-lake-herald-1914-1915/t..., column 1 "TROOPS QUIET MOB" says that about half a dozen men fell when Diser ordered to fire in the mob. The fire started by rioting strikers laid large parts of the town in ruins, see the Bisbee daily review., January 14, 1916, Image 1.

Moreover, she is one of only six women recipients of the Ordre de la Libération." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89milienne_Moreau-Evrard More at: www.ordredelaliberation.fr/fr_compagnon/327.html fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89milienne_Moreau-%C3%89vrard

She was the actress Beatrice "Minnie" Ashley, 1878-1946 (broadway.cas.sc.edu/content/minnie-ashley). In 1903, she married William Astor Chanler (June 11, 1867 – March 4, 1934), soldier, explorer, and U.S. Representative from New York, third son of John Winthrop Chanler of the Dudley–Winthrop family and Margaret Astor Ward of the Astor family. "They had two sons, William Astor Chanler, Jr. and Sidney Ashley Chanler, before separating amicably in 1909. William Astor Chanler, Jr. (1904–2002) was a published historian. Sidney Ashley Chanler (1907–1994) was a public relations executive who married Princess Maria Antonia of Braganza, daughter of the Duke of Braganza and Princess Elisabeth of Thurn and Taxis, in 1934." (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_A._Chanler). Another photo of her and her sons is in the El Paso herald., July 02, 1918, HOME EDITION, Page 8 (the sons called William and Ashley). At that time, she was president of the French Heroes Fund. In the Bisbee daily review., February 01, 1914, Page 3 (with photo), she was labeled as one of the best sculptresses of the day.

Wikipedia leaves out mention of Theodore Chanler, another Chanler named as pictured here, who appeared in New York among "children of society" in a patriotic pageant along with William and Ashley in 1915. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0D17FF355B1373... This may be Theodore Ward Chandler (1902-1961), music teacher and composer, "one of 8 children of well to do parents". However, the biographical entry says he was the youngest of the 8. books.google.com/books?id=m3S7PIxe0mwC&pg=PA1321&... And this book mentions that T.W. Chanler was the son of Winthrop Astor Chanler, not William Astor Chanler (his brother). Too many Astors and too many Chanlers! books.google.com/books?id=F3hrfQtAVeYC&pg=PP68&dq... Theodore Ward Chandler was the namesake and godson of Theodore Roosevelt, who attended his christening: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20813FE3F5F12738... In any event, this picture would not seem to be from 1916, as dated, given the birth dates of all the junior Chanlers in question. Given the pose of the portrait, I think the picture is of Sidney Ashley Chanler, not cousin Theodore.
Here are pictures of William and Theodore in that pageant: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1915-03-06/ed-... chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1915-04-11/ed-...
We'll add "Minnie" and leave the boys alone, for now.

Gwendolyn Nash Gorman, Dec. 8, 1890 - Oct. 23, 1966 (www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=70599927). An article about her engagement to Douglas Gorman is in The New York Times, October 14, 1911 There is a photo of her and her sister, Mrs. Culver McWilliam, in The sun., April 09, 1916, THIRD SECTION, Page 2. Mrs. Culver McWilliam was Eleanor A. Nash, see The sun., April 02, 1916, THIRD SECTION, Image 22, Col. 6. Douglas Gorman was a son of William Henry Gorman (August 29, 1843 – July 7, 1915) (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Henry_Gorman) and a nephew of Senator Arthur Pue Gorman (March 11, 1839 – June 4, 1906) (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Pue_Gorman).

Princeton Alumni Weekly, Vol 44, No 8., Nov 12, 1943, page 10 books.google.com/books?id=CRRbAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA29-IA49&a... indicates that Douglas (Princeton '03) had at least two children, sons Douglas, Jr, (Princeton '35) and Arthur (Princeton '38). A Princeton yearbook entry for another son, Edmund, www.e-yearbook.com/yearbooks/Princeton_University_Nassau_... says "EDMUND NASH GORMAN Ted Gorman was born July 2?, 1914, in Catonsville, Md. He is the son of Douglas Gorman ' 03, and Shirley Maud Gwendolen Nash. His father is president of the Cumberland Coal Company. He has four brothers, one of whom is Douglas Gorman, Jr., ' 35-" So a starting hypothesis is that these two children are Douglas, Jr and Edmund, the oldest of five Gorman boys.
We'll update with Gwen's info.  Thanks!

"Anna Fitziu (April 1, 1887 - April 20, 1967) was an American soprano who had a prolific international opera career during the early part of the 20th century. Her signature roles included Fiora in L'amore dei tre re, Mimi in La Boheme, Nedda in Pagliacci, and the title roles in Isabeau, Madama Butterfly, and Tosca. After her singing career ended, she embarked on a second career as a voice teacher. Among her notable pupils was opera singer Shirley Verrett." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anna_Fitziu She is probably seen here in connection with her role in the world premiere of Enrique Granados's Goyescas at the Metropolitan Opera on January 28, 1916. A number of photos of others connected with that production are in the Bain collection near to this one. archives.metoperafamily.org/archives/scripts/cgiip.exe/WS... See also
www.flickr.com/photos/rinascente/9693566606/ :O=)

From the Bismarck daily tribune. [N.D.], January 08, 1916 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042242/1916-01-08/ed-... "New York papers related not long ago how two musical critics engaged in a fist fight white discussing the qualities of Miss Anna Fitziu's voice. This brought Miss Fitziu into the limelight, and now it is announced that Gatti-Casazza, who manages the .Metropolitan Opera company, has been converted to the way of thinking of Miss Fitziu's fighting friend, and has given her the role previously played by Lucretia Bori, the Spanish prima donna, in the Spanish opera Goyescas." Following this story up, I find in The Washington Times., November 20, 1915, HOME EDITION, page 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1915-11-20/ed-... "-Anna Fitziu, who used to be well known as Anna Fitzhugh In the "Wizard of Oz," but who Is singing more pretentious music now, gave a musicale at the Hotel Biltmore. Two of the audience who sat side by side to hear her were William Thorner, a music teacher, and Andra de Segurola of the Metropolitan Opera House forces. As Thorner had trained Miss Fitziu's voice since she left musical comedy he felt that he had a right to criticize her singing. He turned to Segurola and said: "Too bad, too bad. She's not In good voice today, and anyhow she has made a poor selection of songs." ' Segurola, who is said to have a great personal Interest ln Miss Fltziu. objected strongly, saying that Thorner had no right to utter such criticisms, One word led to another, and the smart audience suddenly saw Thorner jump to his feet and pump rlght and left rapidly Into Segurola's face. The opera singer clinched, and the two men thrashed around the room. Then Mlss Kitziu ran to them and managed to quell the battle. She soothed Begurola's injured face, for the singer's eye was badly swollen. Later ln the day the quarrel between the two men was patched up. When Miss Kltzlu was playing In "The Wizard of Oz" at the Park Theater it was reported that she was engaged to Dave Montgomery of Montgomery and Stone. One of her most ardent admirers at the time was E.R. Thomas, who gave a dinner in her honor et the Hotel Ansonia which made the guests gasp over the elaborate menu and the handsome favors."

I wonder if the photo on the table is of Segurola. The Bismarck tribune., November 30, 1920, page 5 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042243/1920-11-30/ed-... reports that Fitziu and Segurola were to be married after a five-year romance.
I wondered about that too, but the picture is very blurry, even at the highest resolution.

Grace George (1879–1961) was a well known actress, director, producer and writer. She both produced and starred in Major Barbara, by George Bernard Shaw, which had it's U.S. premier at the Playhouse Theatre on Broadway on December 9, 1915. Grace George (real name: Grace Dougherty) married producer William A. Brady (1863–1950) in 1899, and was stepmother to his daughter, Alice Brady (1892–1939), (real name: Mary Rose Brady). A son William Brady Jr. (1900–1935) was born in 1900. [1] [2] [3] [4]   There is also a photograph in the LOC Collection on Flickr of Grace George dressed in her role as Mrs. Cynthia Karslake in The New York Idea. The play opened September 28, 1915, at the Playhouse Theatre and was played in repertory with Major Barbara.

"Johanna Gadski (15 June 1872 – 22 February 1932) was a German soprano blessed with a secure, powerful, ringing voice, fine musicianship and an excellent technique. These attributes enabled her to enjoy a top-flight career in New York City and London, performing heavy dramatic roles in the German and Italian repertoires." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johanna_Gadski Inscription on the photo says "To Lieut. Hodgkinson with best wishes and in remembrance of my "Liebestod" Record - Johanna Gadski - 1915" IMO "Liebestod" (love-death) is a scene (aria) in Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" (and "record" may stand for "scene" in this context I presume).

"Record" may actually mean "recording." www.youtube.com/watch?v=C0fxxXroV1o is an upload of a recording she made in 1907 for Victor. The sound recording on Youtube is accompanied by some still photos, including another autographed copy of this one.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] Maybe - but I don't think that this track from 1907 has any relation to the photo from 1915. The inscription could refer to an audio recording in 1915 of course (though I hardly can imagine what a British Officer has to do with an audio recording). And if it refers to a gramophone record (disc), why is it on a photograph?

Or perhaps Johanna Gadski sang this aria louder than any other opera singer before ... ;-)

@B-59: I was imagining that the photo is promotional material that she had around to autograph for adoring fans and that the British Officer came up to her in 1915 and told her how much he loved the 1907 recording.
It looks like she also recorded the aria in 1915: victor.library.ucsb.edu/index.php/matrix/detail/200006031...
Thanks for all the research on Gadski. It looks like we can at least add a few facts to the description, even if the full meaning of her inscription remains somewhat elusive!

Charles A. Oberwager was a New York lawyer who is mentionned in connection with several trials in the newspapers. According to New-York tribune., May 05, 1917, Page 16, column 3, he was prominent in many sorts of German-American affairs and was appointed attorney of the Labor's National Peace Council. In the von Rintelen trial he was counsel for one of Rintelen's co-defendants, Jacob L. Taylor. Jacob L. Taylor then is possibly the other man in the photo. Franz von Rintelen: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franz_von_Rintelen Another photo shows him with his wife Anna Oberwager He and his wife were law partners, and they had two children. Later, their son Edwin served as a Justice of the New York Supreme Court (according to www.nywba.org/documents/NYWBAfounders.pdf)

On the other hand, a Jacob C. Taylor of East Orange, N.J., President of the Peace Council, is mentonned in The New York Times, December 30, 1915 together with David Lamar, „the Wolf of Wall Street“ and Charles A. Oberwager. Oberwager was Taylor's lawyer and Taylor was obviously paroled. According to The New York Times, May 18, 1917, the Labor's National Peace Council was alleged to have been an instrument created by Captain Franz von Rintelen and David Lamar to carry on the German propaganda. Confusingly, the former President of the council is named „Jacob A. Taylor“, but it's presumably the same man. See also The Evening News - Dec. 29, 1915 And in New-York tribune., May 21, 1917, Image 1, column 2, the same man is named "Jacob L. Taylor"!

B-59: Wow, this is a tricky one! We can certainly expand Oberwager's name, but may retain the current identification of J. C. Taylor until other evidence surfaces to definitively identify him.  Thanks for searching!

"Mihajlo Idvorski Pupin, Ph.D, LL.D. (Serbian Cyrillic: Михајло Идворски Пупин; 9 October 1858 – 12 March 1935), also known as Michael I. Pupin, was a Serbian physicist and physical chemist. Pupin is best known for his numerous patents, including a means of greatly extending the range of long-distance telephone communication by placing loading coils (of wire) at predetermined intervals along the transmitting wire (known as "pupinization"). Pupin was a founding member of National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA) on March 3, 1915, which later became NASA." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mihajlo_Pupin A photo of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics in 1915 with Prof. Pupin in The North Platte semi-weekly tribune., May 07, 1915, Image 11 In 1916 he was - consul of Serbia - invoved in an affair with a stamp dealer, see The New York Times, July 4, 1916 (second article, "SUMMONS FOR PROF. PUPIN")

Besides of that, I think now that the man on this photo has much more similarity to Robert Bacon (July 5, 1860 – May 29, 1919), American statesman and diplomat (he served as United States Ambassador to France from 1909 until 1912) (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Bacon) and the LOC title is wrong. He was the father of Robert Low Bacon. On November 4, 1915 Bacon (the former ambassador) went to Europe in connection with the work of the American Ambulance Hospital in Paris and also in connection with the service of the Harvard surgical unit (The Washington times., November 05, 1915, HOME EDITION, Page 15, column 1). He came back in December, see above. Another report of the arrival of R. Bacon, the former ambassador, in the Bismarck daily tribune., December 30, 1915, Image 5, column 5.
Yes, no question this is the elder Robert Bacon, not the son Robert Low Bacon. Good catch.
B-59 and artolog: Based on my own looking as well as your research, I agree that this is actually Robert Bacon, 1860-1919. We will amend the record to reflect the correct Bacon!

LOC, note mistranscription of "O'Hara" from negative. Dorothea Warren O'Hara (1873–1972). American artist, particularly working in enamels and ceramics. In December, 1915 she won the Lifetime Membership Prize from the National Arts Club. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F1071FFA3E5F1773... "O'Hara was born in Missouri but settled in the New York area, where she was educated at the Chase School. The artist went on to become a noted craftswoman, expressing her talents in a wide range of media, including pottery and ceramics, sculpture, and painting. She was also a writer, active in the Pen and Brush Club and the American Ceramics Society. Newspaper articles from southern Connecticut in 1926 and 1932 give some insight into her activities at the time. O'Hara exhibited at the Panama Pacific International Exposition of 1915, at Paris Salons, and at the prestigious Grand Central Art Galleries in New York City. Is this photograph an autochrome?

Prokudin-Gorskii followed the development of the autochrome closely. But he used a very different method to achieve color photographs. The technique involved multiple exposures of the same scene through blue, green, and red filters; then, combining the three images into a single, full color scene--either printed on paper, or, projected like a slide. This tricolor method was more time consuming than an autochrome, but it yielded vivid, lifelike color. For a full description of how the tricolor method worked, see www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/prok/process.html and www.loc.gov/exhibits/empire/making.html, which includes a picture of the camera. -- Helena (LOC)

It is one sheet of glass (roughly 10 inches by 3 inches) but three different exposures. Each "frame" was exposed separately as the glass plate negative "dropped" past the camera lens. There's enough time separation between the 3 exposures, with the plate rocking a bit left to right and backward and forward, that aligning the 3 images to create a single color 'composite' is challenging. That's also what causes the streaks of yellow, magenta, and cyan, where the blue, green, and red-filtered areas don't overlap completely.. Blaise Aguera y Arcas figured out an exposure time from a photo that includes the moon: "Given the radius of the moon, its distance from the Earth, and its period of revolution, it can be calculated that the moon moves across the Earth's sky by its own diameter in about 2.1 minutes. The moon is visible in several of the Prokudin-Gorskii plates. The example above is especially clear. The animation alternates between "warped" color reconstructions based on the green exposure and the red exposure. Between the two exposures, the moon moves by more than 1/6 of its diameter, so it would appear that each exposure took upward of 20 seconds; the whole photo would have taken over a minute. From the brightness of the sky and the fairly short shadows, we can assume that this photo was taken during broad daylight. On an overcast day, the exposure would need to have been longer; indoors, much longer." Photo, www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/prok/item/prk2000000241/ For a full description of how the color method worked, see www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/prok/process.html and www.loc.gov/exhibits/empire/making.html (which includes a picture of the camera). Helena (LOC)

The above image is not really a very good representation of the photograph. It has been over-sharpened, and the colors are not accurate. The coat of the young man in the center, for example, comes out as green when you process the shot, yet here it is grey; in effect, it has been de-saturated. I would ask the Library too, whether it has considered re-scanning the glass plates. They were scanned a long time ago now, and at only 1000dpi; I think rescanning at 2400 would reveal even more detail, and would make the process of aligning the plates easier. www.flickr.com/photos/theonemacduff/7175005104/in/album-7...

Duffy'sTavern: We've noticed a variety of results from the many people that have created their own composites as you have. It's true that the alignment, the balance of the color layers, and corrections for warping and subject movement can have an impact on the outcome. We've presented one color compositing approach in this album. Described here: www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/prok/process.html We've shared links to the efforts of some others here: www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/prok/method.html#other The Library of Congress doesn't have imminent plans to rescan the negatives.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/phil_loc]  Wow. I never expected a response. Thanks! And sorry to hear that there are no imminent plans; but perhaps in the future..... People forget that while 19th and early 20th century photography was cumbersome and primitive, by current standards, lenses, by contrast, had already undergone a couple of centuries of development, thus, the detail possibly captured by old photographs is often astonishing, as good as, or better than current digital efforts. Speed Graflex images, for example, if scanned at even 1500dpi, can easily yield a detailed, 40 megapixel image. And as with Prokudin-Gorskii, I'm willing to bet that more detail yet can be recovered from such images by scanning in the 4800dpi range. Just my opinion, of course.....

This is probably taken on their arrival on 12/23/15 in New York aboard the Holland-America liner Rotterdam for a short holiday leave. An account here: select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0B14FE3B5B1773...

Elliott C. Cowdin: ralph.smith.angelfire.com/Flying_Corps/Pilots/ElliottCowd... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] True, this photo is certainly taken at this occasion, see New-York tribune., December 24, 1915, Page 2 or Omaha daily bee., December 28, 1915, Image 1, with similar photos.

Apparently, the publicity generated by the visit of these 3 American fliers was a major catalyst in forming the Lafayette Escadrille (Escadrille Américaine) and the Lafayette Flying Corps in 1916. Here's an account of Cowdin's life with more information about the importance of the event pictured here: "In December of 1915 Cowdin and fellow countrymen Norman Prince and William Thaw were granted a month's permission to America. They arrived in New York on 23 December aboard the SS Rotterdam. Their furlough, though intended as "a short rest", furthered the cause for an American squadron when the Government of France realized the interest the three American volunteers had created during their visit to the United States. The pilots became the focus of the eastern press who doggedly pursued them in spite of their reluctance to speak of their duties. Both sides of the European War seized upon the press coverage: the Allied supporters citing the flyers' example in a plea for America's intervention, while German sympathizers condemned their participation as a violation of U.S. neutrality and demanded their internment. Upon their return to France, the three Americans' desire to form an all-American squadron was enhanced as the French Government realized that just such an organization would be useful in galvanizing America's sympathy for their cause." rdisa.pagesperso-orange.fr/html/Pages/Elliot%20Cowdin%20E... See also:

It's him. He arrived in New York, like others in this series of photos, on the liner Rotterdam on December 23, 1915, and had some pithy comments about Wilson and his policy of non-intervention in the war: "With the exception of the Kaiser, outside of Germany, [Wilson is] the most unpopular head of government in the world." Also some prescient words about the war: "I do not think there will be peace for at least 2 years and possibly 5." select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20714FE3B5B1773... The second date on the negative, 3/4/21, is when Harvey was made U.S. ambassador to Great Britain.

It is certainly Pu Lun (caption on the photo says PU, not PI). In 1904 he was the Chinese envoy at the St. Louis exposition, see p.e. The St. Louis Republic., May 07, 1904, Page 8. There was even an advertising with his face: The St. Louis Republic., May 29, 1904, PART I, Page 10. Date on photograph says 1912 (?) at the bottom and 12/20/15 on the sticker. There are some references of him in the newspapers of 1912, e.g. The Mathews journal., February 01, 1912, Image 6 column 5. Unclear what happened in 1915. Pu Lun was executed in 1917 (according to The Ogden standard., July 05, 1917, 4 P.M. CITY EDITION, Image 1, last column) (PS: this report seems to be a canard, see below)
He wears the sash and star of the Japanese Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum that country's highest order founded in 1876. Wikipedia does not include him in their list of recipients.

On December 16, 1915, the New York times ran a dispatch from Peking stating that Pu Lun had been made Chairman of the Council of State. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40712F7395D1673... However, that report of Pu Lun's execution appears to be in error. Prince Pu Lun's name is now commonly transliterated as Pulun. Here is a Chinese wikipedia entry for Pulun, 11/10/1874-1/21/1927, who was the envoy to the St. Louis world's fair in 1904. zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%BA%A5%E5%80%AB) Late Qing dynasty family tree: books.google.com/books?id=tgq1miGno-4C&lpg=PA238&...

Composer and pianist Enrique Granados Campiña This set of 4 pictures are probably related to the Metropolitan Opera production of Granados' "Goyesca", which premiered in January, 1916. A portion of the review of opening night by Richard Aldrich, from the Met's website: "The Spanish colony most rarely has an opportunity to celebrate the success of a fellow countryman in opera, and took the fullest advantage of this one. There was ecstatic applause after each of the first two tableaux and more at the end of the opera. The singers were again and again recalled. Mr. Granados came frequently; Mr. Periquet came; Messrs. Setti, Spech and Bavagnoli came, and none was left unhonored. Vast wreaths were given the two authors of the opera, a bronze one to Mr. Granados. The applause on this occasion doubtless had much of the fictitious value of first-night applause, to which was added the element of national pride. But there seemed to be evidence to show that the brilliantly exotic little opera-it lasts hardly an hour-had really made an impression an the general public, and that it may turn out to have more than the transitory attraction of many new additions to the operatic list." Possibly Isa Kremer en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isa_Kremer "a soprano of Russian Jewish descent who at various times of her life held citizenship in Russia, the United States, and Argentina. She first drew notice as a teenager for her revolutionary poetry which was published in an Odessa newspaper. She began her professional singing career as an opera singer in Europe during the second decade of the 20th century. By the time of her relocation to the United States in 1924, she had abandoned her opera career in favor of performing as a concert soloist and recitalist." If so, this would be another photo from the 1920s. She first came to the States in the autumn of 1922.

Wife of (Louis) Aston Knight (1873–1948), a French-born American artist noted for his paintings of landscapes (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_Aston_Knight). Aston's father, a painter as well, was already named Ridgway, see The Salt Lake tribune., February 12, 1911, Page 19 with a extensive article about the Knight family. According to wikipedia, she was Caroline Ridgeway Brewster. She had two sons, Ridgway Brewster Knight and George William Knight, and a daughter, Diane Knight Todd. records.ancestry.com/Caroline_Ridgway_Brewster_records.as... says she was Caroline Ridgway Brewster, born in Rochester, New York, USA on 21 Sep 1882 to Elisha Franklin Brewster and Sarah Ridgway Macy and had 4 children. She passed away on 26 Jun 1959. Ridgway Brewster Knight was born in Paris, France on 12 Jun 1911 and died on 14 Aug 2001 in Le Touquet, France (records.ancestry.com/Ridgway_Brewster_Knight_records.ashx...)
The New York Herald ran an almost identical picture of their arrival from France on 12/15/1915 aboard the SS Espagne of the French Line. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald...

Clara Washington Lopp alias Lady Nicotine, goddess of pipe dreams, see the New-York tribune., January 23, 1915, Page 9, with photo. She was a nurse at front and collected 45'185 pounds of tobacco for the allied soldiers. In may 1916, her husband George Washington Lopp attacked her and the stepdaughter after a quarrel and beated both into unconsciousness, see The evening world., May 16, 1916, Final Edition, Image 3. The article says that Lopp made a fortune as professional dancing master in Paris, where he introduced the cakewalk. His wife was the daughter of the Paraguayan Minister to Paris. See also New-York tribune., May 16, 1916, Page 3 About Lopp's carreer as dancing master: The Salt Lake tribune., December 10, 1911, Second News Section, Image 17, with photo.
Another photo of her with comment

This photo was apparently taken on their arrival from France aboard the French Line's SS Espagne. An account of their arrival with daughter Sofia, as well as their activities (Mr. Lopp was a Red Cross official and she was Lady Nicotine) is in the December 16, 1915 New York Herald. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald...

George W. Lopp died in 1955, age 90, "one of the oldest Americans living in Paris": select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9901E6DA113EE63B... Sophia (Sofia) Machain, stepdaughter of George W. Lopp, married photographer James Slevin in May 1916, in Paris--because Lopp was considered violent, Slevin got a gun permit in time for the civil wedding ceremony: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1916-05-18/ed-... www.slavens.net/news/fiancee_attacked.htm query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20E1FF93D5F13738...

Another Bain photo taken at this same event  ran in the Sunday (Portland) Oregonian on July 16, 1916 with the caption" G. Washington Lopp, connected with the American ambulance at Neuilly, near Paris, was arrested In Paris for beating his wife and step-daughter, Sofia Machain, with a chisel. He was released.
"http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-07-23/ed-1/seq-58/

"Richard Bennett (May 21, 1870 – October 22, 1944) was an American actor who became a stage and silent screen matinee idol over the early decades of the twentieth century." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Bennett_%28actor%29 His wife was Adrienne Morrison, "a semi-successful stage actress" (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrienne_Morrison). He was one of the inventors of the Apache dance in Paris 1908. www.imdb.com/name/nm0561099/ www.streetswing.com/histmai2/d2movet1.htm en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apache_%28dance%29 See extensive article about him in archive.woodbridgelibrary.org/Archive/TheWoodbridgeLeader... From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southend-on-Sea "Southend-on-Sea is home to the world's longest pleasure pier, built in 1830 and stretching some 1.33 miles from shore. Since 1986, a diesel-hydraulic railway has run the length of the pier, replacing the electric service which opened in 1890. The pier has been beset by fires; a fire in 1995 destroyed the bowling alley at the start of the pier and another fire in October 2005 damaged the far end of the pier. The pier was also run through by a boat in 1984."

Compare this with the next photo in the photostream and note the differences.
The Lion Hotel has a list of what it sells and the licensee's name in this picture , only black panels in that shot. The flag poles are not on the buildings there, but have been added here. And significantly, the clock tower is now visible at the end of the road.
The clock tower was built in 1898 to mark the Diamond Jubilee of Queen Victoria in 1897. Its presence in this picture and absence in the next shot shows that that photo was taken earlier.

Tabernacle of Billy Sunday in Trenton, Michigan. "William Ashley "Billy" Sunday (November 19, 1862 – November 6, 1935) was an American athlete who, after being a popular outfielder in baseball's National League during the 1880s, became the most celebrated and influential American evangelist during the first two decades of the 20th century. ... he (Sunday) insisted that towns build him temporary wooden tabernacles at their expense. The tabernacles were comparatively costly to build (although most of the lumber could be salvaged and resold at the end of the meetings), and locals had to put up the money for them in advance. This change in Sunday's operation began to push the finances of the campaign to the fore. At least at first, raising tabernacles provided good public relations for the coming meetings as townspeople joined together in what was effectively a giant barnraising. Sunday built rapport by participating in the process, and the tabernacles were also a status symbol, because they had previously been built only for major evangelists such as Chapman." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billy_Sunday Photos of Billy Sunday:

Anton is a relative, a cousin, several generations back.  He was arrested in 1915 served 1 year on jail, joined the Army around 1917 and then became a US Citizen. He was actually intervied in a newspaper on the day he became a US Citizen.   His full name is Anton Frout Mente, and he later changed his name to Frank Mente.  He was born in 1892 in BakonySzentLaszlo, Vesprem, Hungary.  He immigrated to the US in 1906  He died in the 1960's and is buried in a Veterans Cemetery in Long Island.  He worked as an electrition in New York in Brooklyn.  He never married.

In Riverside Park, New York City, December 6, 1915. Part of the text on an historical marker nearby:

In New York, a prominent group of citizens formed a Joan of Arc monument committee in 1909. Their efforts coincided with those of a young sculptor, Anna Hyatt Huntington, to create a sculpture of Joan. Her first version, in which she emphasized “the spiritual rather than the warlike point of view,” was submitted to the prestigious Salon in Paris. It received an honorable mention from the jury, nevertheless skeptical that such an accomplished work of art could have been made solely by a woman.

The New York monument committee, headed by J. Sanford Saltus, was so impressed by her work, that they awarded her the commission. Architect John van Pelt was retained to design the pedestal, which is made of Mohegan granite composed of Gothic-style blind arches, decorated with coats of arms. A few limestone blocks from the tower in Rouen where Joan of Arc had been imprisoned were incorporated into the base. Van Pelt situated the monument at the top of the steps in the park island at 93rd Street and Riverside, and had planted a screen of trees to disguise the buildings.

Huntington’s version is both heroic and infused with naturalistic detail. For Joan’s armor, she conducted research at the arms and armory division of the Metropolitan Museum of Art; the refinement of the equine anatomy was based on a horse borrowed from the fire department of her native town of Gloucester, Massachusetts. Her niece posed astride a barrel, as she modeled the figure, first nude, then in costume.

On December 6, 1915, the sculpture was unveiled in an elaborate ceremony, which included a military band and French Ambassador Jean J. Jusserand. Mrs. Thomas Alva Edison was among those selected to pull the cord that released the shroud. Huntington went on to have a long and illustrious career, and also sculpted the statue of the Cuban patriot, José Martí (1965), which stands at Central Park South and Avenue of the Americas. A replica of Joan of Arc stands in front of the Palace of the Legion of Honor in Golden Gate Park, San Francisco.

In 1939, Parks repaired Joan’s sword, which had been broken, repatined the bronze statue, and repaired the staircase. In 1987, the sculpture again underwent a full conservation financed by the Grand Marnier Foundation through the Municipal Art Society’s Adopt-A-Monument Program.

"Katherine Leckie, a journalist, editorial consultant, and press agent, was born in Kingston, Ontario. Over the course of her career as a journalist she reported for the Chicago Chronicle, Chicago American, and the New York Evening Journal. She held editorial positions with the Delineator in 1907-1908, Woman's Magazine from 1908 to 1912, and the Housekeeper in 1913. Following her career as a writer and editor, she founded her own New York-based editorial consulting and public relations firm, through which she met the Hungarian pacifist Rosika Schwimmer in 1914. Leckie managed Schwimmer's 1914-1915 United States lecture tour, contracting with women's clubs and pacifist organizations in over twenty states across the country to schedule Schwimmer as a speaker. The 1915 season was cut short, however, due to both women's attendance at the International Congress of Women at The Hague, and their involvement with the Henry Ford Peace Expedition of 1915-1916. Leckie was hired as public relations and press manager for the Ford Peace Expedition, although her duties stretched far beyond public relations. In particular, she contributed to the process of selecting and courting guests for the expedition, and brought on the four female journalists who accompanied the voyage. Following her time with the Ford Expedition, Leckie served as organizer of news distribution for the Conservation Division of the Food Administration in Washington D.C. in 1917, and the director of publicity for the Y.W.C.A. Free Milk for France campaign of 1918. Katherine Leckie passed away in 1930." from biographical material associated with Katherine Leckie's papers in the collections of the New York Public Library. www.nypl.org/sites/default/files/archivalcollections/pdf/...

www.hms-victory.com/index.php?option=com_content&view... One of the most famous ships of all time, I suspect. From the site above: "HMS Victory has now been in commission for over 200 years and is the oldest commissioned warship in the world." A major restoration effort is currently under way. So she is currently in drydock and without her topmasts. See www.historicdockyard.co.uk/news/news393.php I recently learned that during the Napoleonic Wars, French prisoners of war were housed in hulks of ships in Portsmouth and one of their occupations was to make models of ships. With the assistance of guards and officers, they traded the ships and got commissions for models of particular ships. I saw one of the Victory in the maritime museum in Oinousses, Greece (a small island in the Aegean) a few weeks ago, and www.bonhams.com/auctions/15617/lot/364/ shows another that was auctioned in 2007.

It is also the main entrance to Christ Church College in the University of Oxford. Hard to believe, perhaps, that one of Britain's greatest architects took time out from doing his favoured Baroque-style masterpieces (as in the Sheldonian Theatre in your adjacent photo: flic.kr/p/fgT6UX), to go 'gothic' here, presumably to blend with the rest of the college here.
The chapel here was called a cathedral. Is it still?
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/70251312@N00] Yes www.chch.ox.ac.uk/cathedral

Architect: Sir Christopher Wren, one of Britain's greatest architects.  He was a graduate of Wadham College, just round the corner, out of sight to the left of this picture. The building to the left of it is the University's Clarendon Building whose architect was Wren's great pupil, Nicholas Hawksmoor.

The busts of Roman emperors that adorned the fence were still there when I was in Oxford in 1956, but they eventually succumbed to the ravages of acid rain (probably not for the first time). I believe they have been replaced. Maybe we could get Morse on the case?

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/70251312@N00] The heads are only 'said to be' Roman Emperors.  In fact they are somewhat caricature in style and have also been said to be philosophers or 'worthies'.  The battered old heads were eventually replaced, using Loggan's contemporary print of the Sheldonian Theatre to re-construct their original appearance, since the original head were so far gone as to be unrecognizable.

Per Wiki:  Harold Homer Chase (February 13, 1883 in Los Gatos, California – May 18, 1947 in Colusa, California), nicknamed "Prince Hal", was a first baseman in Major League Baseball, widely viewed as the best fielder at his position. During his career, he played for the New York Highlanders (1905–1913), Chicago White Sox (1913–1914), Buffalo Blues (1914–1915), Cincinnati Reds (1916–1918), and New York Giants (1919).

No lesser figures than Babe Ruth and Walter Johnson named him the best first baseman ever, and contemporary reports describe his glovework as outstanding. He is sometimes considered the first true star of the franchise that would eventually become the New York Yankees. In 1981, 62 years after his last major league game, baseball historians Lawrence Ritter and Donald Honig included him in their book The 100 Greatest Baseball Players of All Time.

Despite being an excellent hitter and his reputation as a peerless defensive player, Chase's legacy was tainted by a litany of corruption. He allegedly gambled on baseball games, and also engaged in suspicious play in order to throw games in which he played

Eleftherios Venizelos (full name Elefthérios Kyriákou Venizélos, Greek: Ἐλευθέριος Κυριάκου Βενιζέλος; (23 August 1864 – 18 March 1936) was an eminent Greek revolutionary, a prominent and illustrious statesman, and a charismatic leader of the early 20th century. 
Elected several times as Prime Minister of Greece, serving from 1910 to 1920 and from 1928 to 1932, Venizelos had such profound influence on the internal and external affairs of Greece that he is credited with being "the maker of modern Greece", and is still widely known as the "Ethnarch".
His first entry into the international scene was with his significant role in the autonomy of the Cretan State and later in the union of Crete with Greece. Soon, he was invited to Greece to resolve the political deadlock and became the country's Prime Minister. 
Not only did he initiate constitutional and economic reforms that set the basis for the modernization of Greek society, but also reorganized both army and navy in preparation of future conflicts. Before the Balkan Wars of 1912–1913, Venizelos' catalytic role helped gain Greece entrance to the Balkan League, an alliance of the Balkan states against Ottoman Turkey. 
Through his diplomatic acumen, Greece doubled her area and population with the liberation of Macedonia, Epirus, and the rest of the Aegean islands.

"Anton Ludwig August von Mackensen (6 December 1849 – 8 November 1945), born August Mackensen, was a German soldier and field marshal.[1] He commanded with success during the First World War and became one of the German Empire's most prominent military leaders. After the Armistice, Mackensen was interned for a year. He retired from the army in 1920 and was made a Prussian state councillor in 1933 by Hermann Göring. Mackensen, a nationalist rather than a National Socialist, frequently appeared at Nazi functions wearing his imperial cavalry uniform and became a major symbol of the integration of the Second and Third Reich." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_von_Mackensen

"Erich Friedrich Wilhelm Ludendorff (sometimes referred to as von Ludendorff) (9 April 1865 – 20 December 1937) was a German general, victor of Liège and of the Battle of Tannenberg. From August 1916 his appointment as Quartermaster general made him joint head (with Paul von Hindenburg), and chief engineer behind the management of Germany's effort in World War I until his resignation in October 1918." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erich_Ludendorff "Paul Ludwig Hans Anton von Beneckendorff und von Hindenburg, known universally as Paul von Hindenburg; 2 October 1847 – 2 August 1934) was a Prussian-German field marshal, statesman, and politician, and served as the second President of Germany from 1925 to 1934. Hindenburg enjoyed a long career in the Prussian Army, retiring in 1911. He was recalled at the outbreak of World War I, and first came to national attention, at the age of 66, as the victor at Tannenberg in 1914. As Germany's Chief of the General Staff from 1916, he and his deputy, Erich Ludendorff, rose in the German public's esteem until Hindenburg gradually gained more influence in Germany than the Kaiser himself." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_von_Hindenburg Ludendorff, much later, with Adolf Hitler: An interesting account of Ludendorff from 1917, by H.L. Mencken: www.theatlantic.com/past/docs/issues/17jun/mencken.htm

Magnus von Eberhardt

Magnus von Eberhardt (6 December 1855 – 24 January, 1939) was a Prussian military officer and a German General der Infanterie during World War I. He began his military career in 1874 (at age 19) as a Sekonde-Lieutenant in the 93rd Infantry Regiment at Zerbst. 
At the outbreak of the war, von Eberhardt was Military Governor of Straßburg, then in the German Imperial territory of Alsace-Lorraine. 
On September 1, 1914 he took command of the temporary Corps Eberhardt, named for him. On December 1, 1914 it was established as XV Reserve Corps and renamed as XV Bavarian Reserve Corps in September 1916. On 16 October 1916, he transferred to command X Reserve Corps.
In August 1918, he temporarily took command of the 7th Army from Max von Boehn on the Western Front before going on to command the 1st Army just before the end of the war. 
Von Eberhardt was awarded the Pour le Mérite ((Prussia's and Germany's highest military honour) on 20 May 1917. He was awarded the Oakleaves (signifying a second award) on 22 September 1917.
In 1919, von Eberhardt was appointed to the defense of Eastern Prussia as commander of the Kulmer Land Defence Forces. In the spring of 1919, he received the order to withdraw from the territory of Soldau and Polish troops took possession.
Von Eberhardt died in Berlin on 24 January 1939 at the age of 83.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/toots] @Cassies grandma Interesting you should ask ... ;) There were books written and movies made about the crew of the SMS Emden. A blurb from the back cover of one book: "The Last Cruise of the Emden is the true story of one of the most extraordinary and little-known escapades of World War I. On August 2, 1914, the Emden, a German light cruiser, was steaming peacefully off the China coast when over its wireless came the message that the German Empire was at war. The ship was made ready for action. Sailing to the Indian Ocean under orders, the Emden sank some twenty merchant vessels - most of them British - a Russian cruiser, and a French destroyer. "What followed was a six-month voyage that took the Emden and its crew halfway around the world, fighting heroic battles both on land and at sea, culminating in a dramatic journey across the Arabian desert, which saw the crew survive attacks of malaria, typhus, dysentery, and the murderous onslaught of Lawrence of Arabia's bedouin tribesmen."

Slight correction of the note: the name of the ship is "Ayesha", not Dyesha. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hellmuth_von_Mücke The picture was taken on the occasion of Kapitänleutnant von Mücke's wedding with Carla Finke in June 1915, after his and his men's adventurous return from the South Seas via the Arab peninsula and Constantinople: books.google.de/books?id=8uDIrtb5DzEC&pg=PA77&lpg...

Nicholas II [Russian: Николай II, Николай Александрович Романов, Nikolai II, Nikolai Alexandrovich Romanov (18 May 1868 – 17 July 1918)] the last Tsar of the Russian Empire with his only son Alexei Nikolaevich Romanov (Russian: Алексе́й Никола́евич) (12 August 1904 – 17 July 1918). If this picture was from March, 1917, this was probably taken at what was the Russian Army's headquarters in Mogilev, in present-day Belarus, where the Tsar spent long periods as commander-in-chief. He went there on March 7, 1917, during violent riots in St. Petersburg. He was forced to abdicate the throne on March 15, 1917. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/February_Revolution#Tsar.27s_return... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicholas_II ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9D%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexei_Nikolaevich,_Tsarevich_of_Ru... Czarewitch (on the negative here, written Czarewitsch) is an older variant transliteration of Царе́вич, now more commonly written in English as Tsarevitch, meaning any male son of the Tsar. And see:

The name Kingsgate is related to an incidental landing of Charles II on 30 June 1683 (‘gate’ referring to a cliff-gap) though other English monarchs have also used this cove, such as George II in 1748. The building was later the residence of John Lubbock, 1st Baron Avebury. The building has now been converted into 31 flats." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingsgate_Castle July, 2012 Street View: maps.google.com/maps?q=broadstairs+england,kingsgate+cast... More: "2. circa 1760 Lord Holland built a copy of a Welsh Edwardian castle to house his stables. This soon fell into ruin and the large round tower is all that remains of the original building. In the late C19 it was rebuilt by Lord Avebury. Quadrangular in shape. 2 to 3 storeys flint faced with stone long and short quoins and window dressings. Crenellated parapet. Windows are 3 light mullions." www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-417608-kingsgate-cast...

On a map from 1973, this structure is named "jetty", the pier is at the harbour. An English person seeing this image will tell you this is a pier, one of the hundreds of seaside piers built around our coast by the Victorians. It was apparently named "The Jetty" in the 1850s to distinguish it from the pre-existing Margate Pier Harbour wall - http://www.piers.org.uk/pierpages/NPSmargate.html

There is a danger that title of this image could lead to the location being wrongly confused with 'Wells' in the County of Somerset. The location is more correctly 'Malvern Wells', a location much further north in Worcestershire, in the Malvern Hills. There is no such place as 'Wells, Malvern, England'. So just to recap for clarity, this picture is of a place called Malvern Wells, Worcestershire, England.

This is probably Alene Bergmann, daughter of Francis & Nellie Bergmann, born in the Bronx in April 1900.  Her father was of German descent, and her mother of Swedish.  They lived in the Bronx and in Brooklyn (found in 1900, 1910, 1920 US census and 1915 NY State Census.  In the 1920 census her occupation was given as "model in a hat shop".  By 1925, she had married Raymond Walter and they had one daughter Virginia.  (found in 1930 and 1940 US Census).    I'm adding this here so that one day, one of her descendants might google her name and find her. :)

"Charles Cheers Wakefield, 1st Viscount Wakefield (12 December 1859 – 15 January 1941), was a British businessman," best known as the founder of what is now Castrol, a major motor oil and lubricant manufacturer (now part of BP). He was Lord Mayor of London in 1915 and 1916. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Wakefield,_1st_Viscount_Wak... The Lord Mayor (an apolitical office) takes office on the Friday before the second Saturday in November of his or her one year term, so this photo dates from no earlier than mid-November, 1915. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_Mayor_of_the_City_of_London There is newsreel footage of what is probably the same group of men inspecting these WWI recruits from Trinidad in what appears to be London here: www.britishpathe.com/video/trinidad-troops-aka-to-fight-for A deeper look at the historical and sociological moment when, in late 1915, black soldiers were recruited by England: "Although the British officials were not keen on having blacks serve on the Western Front, the extent of the West Indian agitation, and devastating losses suffered by the Allies, eventually forced the British government to approve the formation of West Indian contingents and their service overseas. By the beginning of October 1915, negotiations relating to the financing of a West Indian contingent and its pay were completed and recruiting began in earnest. With a few minor exceptions it was agreed that the West Indians would be recruited on the same terms and conditions as British recruits." More at: www.bbc.co.uk/history/worldwars/wwone/west_indies_01.shtml

Carl Gottlieb Bünz (* Juli 25, 1843 in Marne (Holstein); † September 15, 1918 in Atlanta) was a German diplomat. From 1914 to 1915 he was the general manager of the Hamburg - American Line in New York. In this role he was responsible for the supply of German cruisers in the Atlantic by neutral ships with coal and provisions. In December 1915 he was therefore tried and sentenced to 18 months in prison for "conspiracy to defraud the United States." The judgment became final after dismissal of the appeal. Bünz began his sentence on 23 April 1918 in the state prison in Atlanta , where he fell ill and died in September 1918, at the day he was reprieved by President Wilson. de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Gottlieb_B%C3%BCnz see also The sun., January 11, 1918, Page 2

Thanks B-59. He came up one other time in Bain. In newspapers of the time his name was spelled both Karl and Carl, and Bunz and Buenz. I found one case where he himself seems to have used Buenz. I'll ask that we add the various spellings to our catalog record.

Founded by African-American educator Booker T. Washington in Tuskegee, Alabama in 1881 as the Tuskegee Normal School for Colored Teachers, later known as the Tuskegee Institute and now as Tuskegee University, Tuskegee is a private, historically Black university. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuskegee_University
I find no direct evidence that this is either the Tuskeegee School or Institute, although that is likely.  The caption says "Hospital-Tuskeegee" and no more.

It's true that the caption doesn't identify the hospital as being connected with the Institute. However, all the circumstantial evidence (its placement in a series of pictures of college activities and people closely connected with the Institute at the time of Booker T. Washington's death, the racial makeup of the nurses and patients, etc.) marks it as almost unmistakably taken in the Institute's hospital. This was John A. Andrew Memorial Hospital, which claimed to be the first full-service hospital for the treatment of Black patients. Perhaps more importantly, due to racial discrimination, it was one of the few places in the Jim Crow South where Black doctors and medical professionals could work. It was opened in February, 1913. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2641895/?page=3 www.encyclopediaofalabama.org/face/Article.jsp?id=h-2410 Also, Tuskegee was and is a very small place (even today, with a university, there are only 11,000 people. The likelihood that it had a second hospital of this kind is very small.

"The Gallipoli Campaign, also known as the Dardanelles Campaign or the Battle of Gallipoli or the Battle of Çanakkale (Turkish: Çanakkale Savaşı), took place on the Gallipoli peninsula in the Ottoman Empire (now Gelibolu in modern day Turkey) between 25 April 1915 and 9 January 1916, during World War I. A joint British and French operation was mounted to capture the Ottoman capital of Constantinople (Istanbul) and secure a sea route to Russia.[6] Following an unsuccessful naval campaign to force a passage through the Dardanelles, an amphibious landing was undertaken on the Gallipoli peninsula. The attempt failed after eight months of heavy fighting and many casualties on both sides; the force was finally evacuated. The campaign was one of the greatest victories of the Ottomans during the war and is considered a major failure by the Allies." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gallipoli_Campaign

Classic North Devon. 

The steep little valley which starts just behind the beach here was the location of one of Britain's most serious flooding disasters in modern times, in the 1950s, following a massive thunderstorm over the Exmoor hills just behind this bit of coast.  All but swept the lower parts of the town away.

Interesting detail is the long straight gulley on the hillside opposite.  This is probably the local funicular railway, unusual in Britain for being water-driven (at least, at the time).
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/brize] The scar on the hillside is definitely the funicular - then still quite new. Its still the longest in Britain and is still water powered

Head of a French commission which arrived aboard the liner Lafayette, see The Liberal democrat, December 03, 1915, Image 8 The commission: The liner Lafayette:

"In the Autumn and Winter of 1915, a body of distinguished and representative Frenchmen visited the United States, their object being to make an investigation of conditions here, having in mind the great need of France in war munitions, the steel in ingot and bar form very much needed for the manufacture of war materials, and the numerous other commodities necessary for prosecution of the war, which had been in progress more than a year." --"A Journey through France in War Time," www.gutenberg.org/files/20464/20464.txt

The commission arrived aboard the new liner Lafayette. Maurice Damour was the head. It had come to the United States to make arrangements for the purchase of American goods to the amont of $ 1.000.000.000 after the war (The Evening herald, November 18, 1915, Page 3). "None of the money, said M. Damour ... will be spent on ammunition. All will be spent for agricultural, industrial and commercial material" (The Liberal democrat, December 03, 1915, Image 8)

The correct names are E. Delasalle-Thiriez, J. Lesueur, L. Trincane and G. Chaffour (The public ledger., December 02, 1915, Image 1 and others). According to The Evening herald, November 18, 1915, Page 3 it's L. Trincano and G. Chauffour.

Luis d'Antin, an American citizen, was chancellor of the American embassy in Mexico and later attached to the Mexican embassy in the US. He suffered a sudden death in San Luis Potosi while enroute to Mexico City with Eliseo Arredondo in 1917, see the Bisbee daily review, January 10, 1917, Page 4 "AMERICAN CITIZEN ATTACHE OF MEXICO EMBASSY IS DEAD".

Francisco Paredo: His correct name was presumably Francisco Peredo, he was the Mexican consul in Phoenix until 1920, see El Paso herald, May 14, 1920, HOME EDITION, Image 1 last column: MEXICAN CONSULATE AT PHOENIX, ARIZONA, CLOSED Bisbee daily review., July 29, 1919, Page 4, second column: MEXICAN CONSUL TO AID IN FIGHT ON MARIHUANA and others only (as I can see) El Paso herald., January 28, 1918, HOME EDITION, Page 3 El Paso herald., January 28, 1918, HOME EDITION, Page 3 third column ("Would Be Carnal House") called him Francisco Paredo

Burroughs, Wellcome & Co were founded in 1880 as a pharmaceutical company. As you can see from the picture they were famous for their Kepler Cod liver oil in Malt extract, a more palatable way of getting vitamins and minerals into children. www.sciencemuseum.org.uk/broughttolife/objects/display.as... Sir Henry Wellcome used the fortune he made from the company to set up the Wellcome Trust, one of the biggest charitable trust devoted to research to improve human and animal health. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wellcome_Trust

Bridge designed by I.K.Brunel to carry the Great Western Railway across the Thames. When constructed in the late 1830's this bridge had the shallowest arch ever built. It was generally expected to collapse. However its still there today, carrying trains of a weight, speed and frequency nobody would ever have though possible then.
As you look at the punts and skiffs in the lock, think of Jerome K Jerome's "Three Men in a Boat"  These are the sort of scenes he was describing.

Rustington was built as a convalescent home in 1897 by Sir Henry Harben, President of the Prudential Assurance Company. Situated on a nine acre site overlooking the sea, the Home was designed by the architect Frederick Wheeler. The Home was designed as a place where working men could convalesce after an illness or accident and enable them to become fully active again. Opened in March, 1897, it was taken over by the Carpenter's Company in 1911 and was extensively modernized in the 1970's. Now, over 100 years later, Rustington welcomes both men and women of all ages and from every walk of life.   Rustington Convalescent Home – Then and Now (100+ years later)   "Rustington Conv. Home (2012) by Canis Major    "Rustington Conv. Home (c.1900) by LOC

La Fortaleza (The Fortress) is the current official residence of the Governor of Puerto Rico. It was built between 1533 and 1540 to defend the harbor of San Juan. The structure is also known as Palacio de Santa Catalina (Santa Catalina's Palace). It is the oldest executive mansion in the New World. Holden Chester Richardson (1878 - 1960), see www.nationalaviation.org/richardson-holden-chester/ aka Holden C. "Dick" Richardson, see www.usni.org/magazines/navalhistory/1987-04/voyage-nc-3 His wikipedia entry: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holden_C._Richardson

In 1919, he was engaged in the transatlantic crossing. He was a pilot in the NC-3 flying boat. The attempt was lead by John Henry Towers. "The flying expedition began on 8 May 1919 when three Curtiss NC Flying Boats, designated NC-1, NC-3 and NC-4, left Naval Air Station Rockaway, New York. The aircraft made intermediate stops in Cape Cod, Massachusetts, Chatham, Massachusetts and Halifax, Nova Scotia before reaching Trepassey, Newfoundland on 15 May 1919. On 16 May they left for the longest leg of their journey, to the Azores. NC-1 and the NC-3 were both forced to land in heavy seas due to dense fog, and neither could take off again. NC-1 subsequently began taking on water and the crew was rescued by the Greek freighter Ionia. The crew of the NC-3, including Towers, managed to keep the NC-3 afloat for 52 hours, water taxiing the craft over 200 miles to Punta Delgada on Sao Miguel Island. NC-4 went on to complete the transatlantic crossing, arriving at Lisbon on 27 May." (from en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Henry_Towers) See photo of the crew of the NC-3 on their arrival in Ponta Delgada. Azores: New-York tribune., June 08, 1919, Page 3, Image 49 The other pilot of the NC-3 was David McCulloch:

"General Sir Ian Standish Monteith Hamilton GCB GCMG DSO TD (16 January 1853 – 12 October 1947) was a general in the British Army and is most notable for commanding the ill-fated Mediterranean Expeditionary Force during the Battle of Gallipoli." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ian_Standish_Monteith_Hamilton other Bain pictures:

This is a detail from John Singer Sargent's "Colonel Ian Hamilton, CB, DSO", (1898), now in the Tate gallery in London. The Tate's description: "General Sir Ian Standish Monteith Hamilton (1853–1947) is here portrayed as a colonel and commander of the 3rd Brigade of the Tirah Expeditionary Force on the N.W. Frontier of India. He would have been in the Battle of Dargai (1897), but broke his leg before the campaign began and rejoined his command only after the fighting was over. This portrait must have been painted soon after his return to England in May 1898, on his appointment to command the Musketry School at Hythe. He later became commander of the Dardanelles Expeditionary Force 1915, and in 1920 published his two-volume Gallipoli Diary. Sir Ian was also a collector and bequeathed Sickert's ‘St Mark's, Venice’ (N05914) to the Tate Gallery. A three-quarter view head and shoulders portrait, 27 1/2×20, inscribed ‘To Mrs Ian Hamilton’, was given by Lady Hamilton to the Scottish National Portrait Gallery in 1941. The sitter wears khaki drill uniform and in the background are regimental colours. (See also N05247.)" www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/sargent-colonel-ian-hamilton... One of 5 (so far) Bain/LOC Commons photos of Gen. This is probably one of the most famous landscape views in the Lake District, if not in England as a whole - little England's little answer to Yosemite. The pair of peaks in the centre are the Langdale Pikes.  The left one of the pair is Pike of Stickle and the right one is Harrison Stickle.  Behind it, to the right, is Pavey Ark.  The steep valley coming down the nearer side of Harrison Pike is Dungeon Ghyll.  The view is taken from Kettle Crag I think, looking NNW. The long sloping shoulder on the L is The Band - well known hikers' slog up on to Bow Fell (out of view to L), or knee-breaking descent from same.  The ridge on the skyline is Rossett Pike.  These mountains always look impressively Alpine in views like this, in spite of being only about 700-800 m a.s.l.  Langdale is a classic glaciated valley with Pavey Ark above it, a classic glaciated cirque (aka corrie, cwm) with the Dungeon Ghyll a classic hanging valley - all text-book examples.  The rocky topography is formed in Ordovician volcanics dating from when the Lake District was part of an island arc.  (Lake District place names are truly poetic - many of them are said to be Norse origin, from when the Vikings settled the area.)
This is a stunningly beautiful image!

Beautiful Portrait

What the firm that still bears his name says about him, helping to explain why he added that E to his last name.: "George A. Touche Founder George A. Touche apprenticed as an accountant in Edinburgh before traveling to London and qualifying as a chartered accountant in 1883. After practicing for six years, he was appointed secretary of the Industrial and General Trust. This appointment was his first involvement with investment trusts, a field in which he would become an acknowledged expert. Although best remembered for the accounting companies he founded, Touche was also deeply involved in civic life. He was a member of Parliament for North Islington from 1910 to 1918. In recognition of his many achievements, Touche was knighted in 1917 and appointed a baronet three years later. Touche was actually born with the surname Touch (pronounced in Scotland to rhyme with "loch"). But his name, when mispronounced "Tutch" by the English, had negative connotations. The Oxford Standard Dictionary gave one definition of "touch" as "to wheedle a sum of money out of someone," which Touche felt was hardly appropriate for an accountant. In 1906, therefore, he changed his name to Touche, its ancient Scottish spelling." www.deloitte.com/view/en_US/us/About/History/Leaders-Shap...

As pointed out, this is a photo from 1927. The four men standing in front of the Loening OL-2 amphibian are Benjamin F. Belcher, James E. Davis, Christian F. Schilt (awarded the Medal of Honor for his heroics in Nicaragua in 1928, and ultimately rising to the rank of four-star Marine Corps general upon retirement in 1957), and Hubert H. Dogan (the caption of "Dogant" is incorrect), all Marine Corps aviators who would take part in a surveying mission photographing the northern coast of Cuba in 1927. The surveying mission is cited on page 26 of the October 2, 1927 edition of the San Antonio Express ("Types of Plane for the New Aircraft-Carriers"): "The Navy Bureau of Aeronautics is well satisfied with the work of Marine Corps flyers in the West Indies, during which they photographed 400 miles of Cuba's northern coast. Two Loening amphibians were employed; Capt. James E. Davis and Lieut. Christian F. Schlit were the pilots. Sergeants B.F. Belcher and H.H. Dogan completed the expedition's personnel. "Most of the region between Cardenas - 75 miles east of Havana - and Nuevitas in Camaguey Province is fringed with islands called cayos. The survey extended from Havana to Nuevitas, and it has given the Hydrographic Office (a Navy bureau) a more nearly accurate map of that sector."
