For people living outside the United States of America, the man in the photograph, "Wilson", is Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president. It would be helpful and make a lot more sense if the people posting this material included that basic information, but no. They give us just "Wilson" in the picture title, just "Wilson" in the accompanying text, and no mention of the man's first name in the tags, just "Wilson" again. A link to the Wikipedia article would also be very helpful--- en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson This kind of thing gives those of us living outside the U.S. the impression that Americans do not distinguish between America and the rest of the world, and that Americans assume everybody, even non-Americans, will know "Wilson" refers to "Woodrow Wilson". This is an example Americans behaving in an insular, cloistered manner, and an example of American exceptionalism. Please stop insulting us with this kind of treatment. And wake up---there is a whole world out there, and America is not the whole world. Thank you.

On October 19, President Woodrow Wilson rode in a private railroad car to Princeton, New Jersey, his nominal home town and legal voting place. He arrived with his fiancee, Edith Bolling Galt [they were wed on December 18], went to the polling place and voted "yes" on the Woman Suffrage Amendment, then left after being in town for ninety minutes. This paragraph appeared the next day in the Daily Princetonian:

PRESIDENT WILSON HERE; VOTES "YES" FOR SUFFRAGE
President Woodrow Wilson yesterday made his second visit to Princeton since college opened. His private car arrived at about 12.20, and he proceeded at once to the seventh district polls in the house of Engine Company No. 3 00 Chambers Street. After voting, the President paid a visit to Professor W. U. Vreeland, and later to Dean Fine. He left Princeton at 1.45 p. m.

arbo: the following will hopefully address your questions about our approach to this collection with respect to how the captions were handled. It was written by the chief of the Prints & Photographs Division. Additionally, please see our webpage of frequently asked questions about the Flickr project in general: www.loc.gov/rr/print/flickr_pilot_faq.html In 2004-06, the Prints & Photographs Division was delighted to receive enough funding to scan all 40,000 glass negatives in the Bain Collection. (See www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/ggbain/digitizing.html.) The funding also had limits, and we had to find an expeditious way to provide basic captions. Rather than decipher and transcribe the handwritten titles and dates directly from the glass plates (very time consuming and thus costly), we relied on a typed set of caption cards that Library staff had made some decades ago by looking at the Bain company’s handwritten index cards as well as notes on the paper sleeves that housed the negatives. The information on the Bain caption cards and sleeves was not always identical to the info on the negatives, but it was usually quite close. We tried to be explicit about the “incomplete” aspects of the titles by putting a note in each record to indicate the preliminary nature of the information: "Title from unverified data provided by the Bain News Service on the negatives or caption cards." Having the digital images go online was a foundation step that made future projects possible. People could now more easily compare the titles on the negatives and the information from the caption cards by enlarging the photo image to see the letters on the negative clearly. Then, flesh out abbreviations, correct misspellings, and add subject information. That’s where the Flickr project has made such an important contribution–the reconciliation and verification of data is now well underway! Some 9,000 Bain photos are in Flickr, which means far better captions for almost 25% of the collection already.

The magic of the Internet!

Since you asked, it's worth mentioning two more things .... (1) Flickr opened The Commons in large part so that people could contribute better information about the pictures in many libraries, archives, and museums. Pictures with limited descriptions and institutions with limited resources are all too common. (See www.flickr.com/commons/ ) If you enjoy seeing how picture puzzles are solved, the National Library of Ireland photostream is well worth a look at www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/ (2) We incorporate the valuable new information that Flickr members provide into the catalog records at the Library of Congress pretty quickly, along with a link that connects to the longer narrative comments in Flickr. But we aren't too often able to re-load those improved records back into Flickr. Also, the new, fuller info might be in a subject note rather than the title; we leave the title as the Bain News Service provided it unless their information is completely wrong. Here's a typical example of an updated record that was reloaded to Flickr in 2012, www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ggb2005014062/ Please keep the improved descriptions coming! Helena (LOC)

PRESIDENT WILSON HERE; VOTES "YES" FOR SUFFRAGE
President Woodrow Wilson yesterday made his second visit to Princeton since college opened. His private car arrived at about 12.20, and he proceeded at once to the seventh district polls in the house of Engine Company No. 3 00 Chambers Street. After voting, the President paid a visit to Professor W. U. Vreeland, and later to Dean Fine. He left Princeton at 1.45 p. m.

This is one of those historical characters you can just follow through headlines... Fall 1915: GERMAN COUNT, MAX LYNAR LOUDEN, ARRESTED ON A MYSTERIOUS CHARGE He Has Been Watched by Washington Agents for Several Months New York, Oct. 14--Count Max Lynar Louden, said to be a civil engineer and inventor of military appliances who was arrested here last night...the count was held on a short affidavit charging suspicion of bigamy..." news.google.com/newspapers?id=jrogAAAAIBAJ&sjid=i2kFA... January 1916: "COUNT LOUDEN IS KEEPING PROMISE Count Charles Max Lynar-Louden indicted in Niagara County on numerous counts charging larceny and recently indicted in New York on a bigamy charge, has made another payment to his wife, Mrs. Rose O'Brien Louden of Albion... the count when released on probation owed approximately $4500 to his wife and he agreed to pay back the sum...." The Evening News, North Tonawanda NY, 31 January 1916, p. 1. April 1916: LOUDEN A BIGAMIST, JURY QUICKLY FINDS Count Gave False Record to Court on His Pedigree 2 WIVES APPEAR IN COURT "...Louden lied when he swore that he was a native American, because the records...showed that he was born in Germany and naturalized here in 1894. Louden also swore that he had never been convicted before, whereas it has been discovered that he was convicted of forgery in Germany and spent three years in prison there. ... he escaped from a German prison, being assisted by the wife of a warden. Aside from the two wives who were produced in court at the bigamy trial, Rose O'Brien of Albion NY and Amelia Wendt of Poughkeepsie, 'Count' Louden is alleged to have made several other attachments. Agents...believe that he has been married not fewer than five times..." New York Times 14 April 1916. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0D11FC3D5F13738... June 1916: MILLION DOLLAR PLOT LAID TO INVADE CANADA "...Count Max Lynar Louden, at one time hunted by the United States Federal authorities as an alleged German spy...has just outlined the details of the proposed invasion of Canada by a German army recruited in the United States....'The German Government had topographical maps carefully prepared by competent agents of every country in the world with which is might possibly have war, and it was from this source that the maps were obtained showing the best routes to carry out the proposed invasion.'... Count Louden, recently convicted of bigamy, was given an indeterminate sentence in the penitentiary by Judge Rosalsky...." Aukland Star, 14 June 1916. paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=AS... Spring 1918: "COUNT LYNAR," BIGAMIST, INDICTED FOR FORGERY New Windsor N. Y., March 21--"Count" Max Lynar Louden, who has just finished a term on Blackwell's Island for bigamy, was arraigned to-day in the Orange County Court on indictments charging forgery, found against him a year ago. "Count Lynar," as Louden terms himself, got 40,000 from his victims... by using a cleverly forged seal of the Austro-Hungarian government. He is said to have had a contract for a million soldiers' knapsacks..." New York Tribune 22 March 1918, p. 5. Fall 1919: "COUNT LOUDEN" GIVEN NEW PRISON SENTENCE Term for Bigamy Followed by Court Verdict of 3 Years for Attempted Forgery chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1919-09-30/ed-... GERMAN COUNT IMPRISONED paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=HN... A NOTORIOUS GERMAN paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=OD...

But wait, there's more... Summer 1921: SING SING PLANE IS A FIZZLE Ossining, N. Y., July 21--The working model of a recently patented airship, 1000 feet long and designed to carry 1000 persons across the ocean, this morning is a wreck in the prison yard at Sing Sing. The tangled heap was the model built in the shops of Sing Sing by 'Count' Max Lynar Loudon, sentenced for forgery.... Loudon was first arrested in 1915 on a charge of bigamy. After making his escape and being recaptured, he entered a plea of guilty to the bigamy charge, and revealed a plot of German reservists to invade Canada. Blanche Oelrichs, the second wife of John Barrymore. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blanche_Oelrichs: "Blanche Oelrichs (October 1, 1890 – November 5, 1950) was an American poet, playwright, and theatre actress known by the pseudonym, "Michael Strange." John Barrymore (his real name was John Sidney Blyth), brother of Ethel Barrymore (Ethel Mae Blythe) was also known as Jack Barrymore (see e.g. The New York Times, January 30, 1907) His wikipedia entry: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Barrymore See also: Evening public ledger., August 06, 1920, NIGHT EXTRA, Image 20 (B. Oelrichs first husband was Leonard M. Thomas) She married John "Jack" Barrymore in 1920, the picture must have been generated in this year or later.

The negative bears two dates, 10-16-15 (when Ms. Oelrichs was 25) and 11-28-28. It looks like they scratched out her name and later replaced it with "Mrs. Jack Barrymore", then used the picture again in November, 1928. At that time, the papers were full of stories generated when John Barrymore took out a marriage license in Los Angeles and disclosed that he had received a divorce from from his (former) wife, a fact previously unknown to the public. [The Wikipedia entry for her says they were divorced in 1925, but that is inconsistent with the November, 1928 account in the New York Times, which said they were separated since about that time, but not divorced.] select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70814F93B5B167A... Barrymore was the second of her three wealthy and famous husbands. Their one child together was the actress Diana Barrymore, who wrote a tell-all autobiography in the 50's describing her life of alcoholism, addiction and professional failure due to same. It was made into a movie as well "Too Much, Too Soon". Here is a transcript of a TV interview of her by Mike Douglas: www.hrc.utexas.edu/multimedia/video/2008/wallace/barrymor... Diana Barrymore died of an overdose of alcohol and drugs at age 38.
Thanks to both of you for your research. What a character! We can certainly fill in her name the next time we update the record.

Kilted Cowboy--We did a doublecheck on this image, as the date on the negative is Oct. 14, 1915. It appears that the construction of the "USS California" depicted here was at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and began at a ceremony attended by Navy Secretary Josephus Daniels on Oct. 14, 1915. (New York Times, Oct. 15, 1915). search.proquest.com/cv_667311/docview/97740621/13E0915002... Later the name of this ship was changed to the USS New Mexico. Another ship which was named the USS California had its keel laid down on 25 October 1916 at the Mare Island Naval Shipyard at Vallejo, California. Daniels did not attend this ceremony. (Los Angeles Times, Oct. 26, 1916) search.proquest.com/cv_667311/docview/160327392/13E09173A... The name change of the ship in this image, from the USS Califonia to the USS New Mexico has created the challenge for identification.

Excellent historical sleuthing, Arden. The mystery of the difference in the image dates and the Mare Island event are now solved, as well as why the event was one year off from the generally chronological order of the Bain photos. The image I linked to above, of course, is from the Mare Island event in October, 1916. A ship's history provided by the New Mexico Council of the Navy League of the United States has this to say about the building of the ship, which was ultimately involved in many battles in the Pacific Theater of WWII: "Authorized by an Act of Congress dated June 30, 1914, construction of Battleship 40 was allocated to the Brooklyn Navy Yard and begun in October 1915. At first scheduled to bear the name CALIFORNIA, the huge finished product was officially labeled USS NEW MEXICO as she plunged down greased ways on April 23, 1917. Sponsor at the elegant launching ceremonies was Miss Margaret C de Baca, daughter of New Mexico’s Governor Ezequiel Cabeza de Baca. For Miss C de Baca and for the state of New Mexico (the first time a U.S. Navy ship had been named NEW MEXICO), it was a red letter day. War-built battleship NEW MEXICO constituted at that time the prime example of engineering prowess, of U.S. naval architectural know-how. Rising ominously from the NEW MEXICO’s deck in a 2-A-2 gun arrangement were four massive steel turrets, each built up entirely of flat armor plates and housing a trio of 14-inch rifles. Most of the 5-inch guns in her secondary battery were spotted strategically in drier positions at upper deck level. Submerged below the waterline were two 21-inch torpedo tubes. Two popular-like cage masts adorned the 624-foot hull (16 feet longer than any previous BB class). Improved compartmentation and the substitution of a graceful clipper bow with bulbous forefoot for the ram bow of earlier capital ships were outstanding features. However, top innovation of all came when the NEW MEXICO was singled out to be the first turboelectric-driven battleship. Prompted by the successful record of the fleet collier JUPITER, pioneer in electric propulsion, Secretary of the Navy Josephus Daniels put his official O.K. on an order to outfit the NEW MEXICO with four mammoth General Electric motors. They would operate the NEW MEXICO’s four propellers and enable her to make her accredited 21 knots. Old time sailors and engineers were quick to voice strong opposition in letters, telegrams and interviews, and soon had the controversy before the House Naval Committee. “It is bound to prove an expensive failure,” argued the protesting experts, “so let some other nation try it first.” The decision of the Committee put the decision squarely up to Secretary Daniels." More at: www.ussnewmexico.net/bb40-history/

In its day The Dripping Well was an extremely popular Victorian attraction. Charabancs (sightseeing wagons) would leave the monument in Hastings each day to bring visitors to this beauty spot. Situated at the head of a picturesque, thickly-wooded glen, the Dripping Well, overhung by a huge beach-tree, was a favourite subject for both artist and photographer.  John Logie Baird is said to have drawn inspiration here for inventing television ("seeing by wireless" as he described it). —Compiled [1] [2] [3]   Dripping Well – Then and Now (100+ years later) The romantic Lovers' Seat was located near here but due to erosion only a stone is left in its place. www.abbotshospital.org/ "The Hospital of the Blessed Trinity or Abbot's Hospital as it is better known today was founded in 1619 by George Abbot, Archbishop of Canterbury as a gift "out of my love to the place of my birth". It was not Abbot's intention to provide a "hospital" in the modern sense of the word but a place of shelter for the elderly poor of the town - 12 single men and 8 single women - under the care of a resident Master. Nearly 400 years after the first residents moved in, Abbot's Hospital continues to offer town centre accommodation within a sociable and supportive environment for local elderly people.. A magnificent Jacobean building listed Grade 1, Abbot's Hospital is opposite Holy Trinity Church where George Abbot is buried and is just yards away from Abbot's memorial statue at the junction of Upper High Street."

"Probably no other woman war worker is entitled to wear more medals than Mrs. Hilda Wynne of the British Red Cross. She came to this country recently to represent the Duke d'Aosta's committee to provide relief for wounded Italian soldiers. Mrs. Wynne saw service on the British, French, Belgian and Russian fronts. She has been decorated with the order of St. John of Jerusalem, the Order of Leopold, the Croix de Guerre, the Mena[?] Star, and Silver and Gold Medal of the Order of St. George (Russian), the Italian War Cross and the Red Cross Order of Merit." --"Most Be-Medalled Woman in the World, Schenectady Gazette (22 February 1919): p. 1. Hilda Wynne was an Englishwoman, a military officer's widow who inherited money and spent it to drive an ambulance in wartime Europe, and to support relief efforts. books.google.com/books?id=1Ao9AAAAYAAJ&lpg=RA6-PA27&a... books.google.com/books?id=oZEVAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA105&... query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60B11FC395E11738... After the war, she kept raising funds for the benefit of disabled veterans of the war. She died 28 January 1923, at the Hotel Meurice in Paris. (New York Times obituary published 1 February 1923.)

"Sir Johnston Forbes-Robertson (16 January 1853 – 6 November 1937) was an English actor and theatre manager. He was considered the finest Hamlet of the nineteenth century and one of the finest actors of his time, despite his dislike of the job and his lifelong belief that he was temperamentally unsuited to acting." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnston_Forbes-Robertson

NYT of April 11, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10717FC3D5F13738... reported on the two of them as Hamlet and Ophelia at the Majestic in Brooklyn. It notes that she was new to New York and that he was getting to the ned of his farewll tour. The sun. (New York [N.Y.]), 06 June 1915. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1915-06-06/ed-... reported that he had sailed for Europe on the Philadelphia and said he might never return. But he clearly did make one further trip. From The Washington times. (Washington [D.C.]) 1902-1939, September 19, 1915, SUNDAY EVENING EDITION, Image 12 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1915-09-19/ed-... "Sir Johnston Forbes-Robertson and his English company, including Mlsa Laura Cowle, the young Scotch actress who scored such a decided success with Forbes-Robertson In the West last season, will sail for New York on September 25 for the final lap 'of Sir Johnston's farewell American tour, which opens at Richmond on October 11." So my guess is that this picture is taken when they arrived.

The Washington Herald., October 08, 1915, page 1, top of column 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1915-10-08/ed-... indicates that Forbes-Robertson arrived in New York on the American liner New York. Lord Aberdeen (in neighboring picture) arrived on the same voyage. So I think this is on the liner New York. Found!! This is almost certainly Der Eiserne Hindenburg—the Iron Hindenburg—which stood next to the Victory Column in the Tiergarten. (The curved structure poking into the frame on the right would seem to match the base of the column.) This would seem likely to be from the unveiling, which was on 4 September 1915—the New York Times account can be read here. These statues were known as "Nail Men" and were used to raise money for the war: for a certain donation you got a nail of a certain color, which you then hammered into the statue. Unsurprisingly this led to some mocking imitations elsewhere. The statue did not do too well. Apparently even before the war was out bits were being stolen for firewood, and in the early '20s the whole thing was sold off as fuel. According to news sources, an artist managed to save the head, only to have it destroyed by fungus. (Love how the statue has magically grown to 110 feet tall!) Nonetheless, the head was apparently rediscovered in 1938 and placed in Berlin's Lehrter train station, only to be finally destroyed during WWII.

The Toll Gate and Toll House on Lower Sandgate Road, Folkestone, Kent. Victoria Pier is in the distance. Lower Sandgate Road was a private toll road running from the harbour to Sandgate and belonged to the Radnor Estate. The brick Toll House was designed by the eminent architect Sir Sidney Smirke, who was responsible for the impressive British Museum's Reading Room, York Minster's nave roof and the Charlton Club in Pall Mall London. It was built in 1847 and replaced the original wooden toll house. Tolls were collected until 1973. In 1980 the Toll House was sold and is occupied today as a private residence. [1] [2] There's an interesting collection of photographs of the Toll Gate House – from the early days to present day – at The Toll Gate.

High Street West, Dorchester, England – Then & Now (100+ years later)   There appear to be only modest changes to this High Street in over a century of time. (The 1890 photograph shows 3 buildings in the foreground that aren't included in the camera position of the 2010 photograph.) The building tinted pink, on the left, in the photo above is The Old Tea House, built in 1635. It continues today as a tea house and restaurant. NYT of September 24, 1915 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0D11F93A5C1373... mentions a Harry Balfe and his "showy chestnut gelding Maximum." This piece is about the first day of the annual Mineola Horse Show. Could be this Harry Balfe (1860-1944), born in Newburgh, NY: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=79663861 The photo is not a perfect match but a possiblity. He bred horses.

More evidence that this could be the right Balfe. beta.worldcat.org/archivegrid/record.php?id=772215754 has a finding aid for the papers of the Harry Balfe born in Newburgh NY in 1860 and they include two awards won by Maximum. If so, his wife is the former May Adams.

A finding aid for Isham family papers mms.newberry.org/html/Isham.html indicates that there were several generations of Ishams with Ralph as first name. NYT of September 17, 1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20F13FE395D16738... indicates that Mr. Ralph Heyward Isham and his young wife, the former Miss Marion Gaynor, were getting a divorce. She was a horsewoman and so it makes sense or her to be keeping company with Harry Balfe and his wife at what seems likely to be a horse show. A Bain photo taken before Marion Gaynor's first marriage is Could be the same woman, although not a certainty. By 1936, according to NYT of Dec 4, 1936 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00A17F83C5A1B7B... [subscription needed] she was about to marry for the fourth time.

I don't understand why the english Wikipedia entry of von Bernsdorff says that he was the German ambassador to the United States AND Mexico. It would be hard to understand that there was only one ambassador to both rather important countries. The german entry of von Bernstorff doesn't mention Mexico at all (only the U.S.). NYT of September 11, 1915 (date written on negative) select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30716F83A5C1373... indicates that at the time, there was a concern about the Germans and Austrians "conspiring to cripple munitions factories" in the U.S., including causing disturbances at Charles M. Schwab's Bethlehem Steel. [Schwab and his wife both have pictures in this batch.] The Austrian ambassador had been asked to leave and this piece suggested that Bernstorff might suffer the same fate and that other staff of the German embassy certainly would. The article mentions that both the Austrian ambassador, Dumba and Schwab were at the St. Regis hotel, that Dumba and Bernstorff had dined at the Ritz-Carlton recently, and Bernstorff visited Dumba at the St. Regis. Clearly journalists were staked out outside the hotels. Presumably this picture was taken at some point during this affair.
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] You are correct.  I have changed the Wikipedia entry to reflect this.

Konstantin Dumba He was the last Austro-Hungarian Ambassador to the United States. On 9 September 1915, Secretary of State Lansing declared him no longer acceptable and requested the Austro-Hungarian government to recall its ambassador. In the note, Lansing charged the ambassador with espionage for having advocated that his government back 'plans to instigate strikes in American manufacturing plants engaged in the production of munitions of war'. On 27 September, the Austro-Hungarian government eventually agreed to recall Dr. Dumba. He left the United States on 5 October. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konstantin_Dumba

Several photos in this batch must have been taken by a photographer (or more) staked out at the St. Regis hotel. See more info and an NYT link at www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/8540263580/in/p...

The Pump Room was built in 1884 as a place where people could come to take the unique thermal mineral water. This was a comb mill at Ashford in the Water near a marble mill. Rowland Holmes made combs from tortoiseshell in the 1850s in a small mill constructed as a secondary user of the marble mill leat. Some ruins of this building remain adjoining the site of the former marble works, slightly downstream. The ruins and old pictures indicate a single-storey stone building, 10 ft x 18 ft inside, with large windows. (from www.derbyshireheritage.co.uk/Menu/Archaeology/Mills.php) The mill is also mentionned in a bulletin of the Park district Mines Historical society about the ashford marble works: „The comb mill, once a picturesque inspitation for generations of artists, has a dilapidated gable remaining togeter with fragments of its old water wheel.“ (www.pdmhs.com/PDFs/ScannedBulletinArticles/Bulletin%2012-..., page 67) The mill was situated around here: maps.google.ch/maps?q=53.2215,-1.717&hl=de&sll=47... I found other pictures of this mill:

"The Sherwood Foresters and Worcestershire and Sherwood Foresters Regimental War Memorial, known as Crich Stand is probably Derbyshire's most famous landmark. Access is allowed to the public and on a clear day it is possible to see seven counties - Lincoln to the East and the Wrekin to the West. " en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crich "Built in 1923 on the site of an older tower called Crich Stand, the Memorial Tower is the destination of an annual pilgrimage on the first Sunday in July. It is 1,000 feet (300 m) above sea level, and has 52 steps to the top. From there eight counties can be seen, including landmarks such as the Humber Bridge and Lincoln Cathedral." So it is the older tower in the photochrom.

www.derbyshirewalking.co.uk/walks/Ambergate1.php uses the abbreviated "Ha'penny Bridge" and indicates that it is on Holly Lane. The bridge crosses the Derwent. From www.peakdistrictonline.co.uk/ambergate-c2533.html "The quaintly named Halfpenny Bridge which crosses the Derwent along Holly Lane was built to carry the Wirksworth road across the river in 1792. On the east bank of the river stood the seventeenth century Ferry House, probably Ambergate's earliest dwelling, where people paid their halfpennies to cross the bridge. The Ferry House was demolished in 1964." So the house in the photochrom is no longer there.
A 1904 photo from a slightly different angle is at www.picturethepast.org.uk/frontend.php?keywords=Ref_No_in...
Street View from the other side, the bridge itself is not visible
street view There are lots of bridges around Ambergate, but I think this is the one.
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deal_Castle in Kent in southeast of England.

"Deal Castle is one of the finest Tudor artillery castles in England. It is among the earliest and most elaborate of a chain of coastal forts, which also includes Calshot, Camber,Walmer and Pendennis Castles. Most were built at great speed between 1539 and 1542 by order of King Henry VIII, who feared an invasion by the Catholic powers of Europe. Its squat, rounded turrets were designed to deflect incoming cannon balls, and acted as platforms from which to fire barrages from increasingly sophisticated artillery pieces. The fort guarded the sheltered anchorage of ‘the Downs’ – the stretch of water between the shore and the hazardous Goodwin Sands, a graveyard of ships. Today you can explore the whole of the castle from the storerooms to the first-floor captain’s residence. A pleasant cycle path links Deal and Walmer Castles along the beachfront." From wikimapia.org/3792644/Deal-Castle-Kent See also johnsmilitaryhistory.com/deal.html for photos outside and in.

Herschel Clifford Parker (b. 1867) was a physics professor at Columbia University, and a founding member of the Explorers Club: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herschel_Clifford_Parker www.diggles.com/ec/ECAbout.html library.osu.edu/projects/frederick-cook/expeditions4.html He married Evelyn Naegele (b. c1886) in spring 1911; they honeymooned in Alaska. She asked the Brooklyn court to grant a divorce in 1925, citing abandonment and failure to support (he'd been gone for five years at that point): cdsun.library.cornell.edu/cgi-bin/cornell?a=d&d=CDS19... Evelyn Naegele Parker remarried to a Lewe Sessions: genforum.genealogy.com/sessions/messages/785.html Her father was artist Charles Frederick Naegele; her maternal grandfather was Major Edwin Jacob Stivers, a Civil War veteran. www.askart.com/askart/n/charles_frederick_naegele/charles... civilwargazette.wordpress.com/2009/10/17/field-desk-of-us... Here's a portrait of her mother, Lisette Stivers Naegele (1857-1926), by Charles Frederick Naegele: www.tnportraits.org/stivers-lizette.htm

Excellent info Penny, thanks. Love the quote from the article about the divorce proceedings, "I am tired of looking after a wife and family, a man with my genius owes himself to mankind in general and cannot be tied down by family routine". Evelyn may have been better off without him I'm guessing...

A Dr. Arthur Bledsoe Cooke (1869-1948), professor of German and French, was US Consul at Patras, Greece, 1910-1919: politicalgraveyard.com/bio/cooke.html#015.79.10 books.google.com/books?id=GSwEAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA95&o... His wife as of 1899 was Stella Viola Crider. Survivors of the Athinai, a ship that was set on fire during WWI. They came home safely on the Tuscania, September 1915. This article: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F60F13FA385B17... Mentions Mrs. Cooke and Miss Coffey: "Another survivor of the Athinai was Mrs. A. B. Cooke, wife of the United States Consul at Patras, who was accompanied by her three little children and a friend, Miss Frances Coffey of Richmond, Va. Mrs. Cooke said that her children had stood the exciting experience of the fire and leaving the ship well, but they had no clothes left except what they had on. Miss Coffey said she saved a hat, a collar, a toothbrush, and a box of pins." From the list of American passengers, the boys here must be Louis Cooke and Earle Cooke. From the passenger list of another trip, it looks like the slightly older sister of Louis and Earle was Mary Cooke. www.ellisisland.org/shipping/FormatTripPass.asp?sship=Pat....
glad to be alive - interesting story which  makes the photograph so much more interesting

Survivors of the Athinai, a ship that was set on fire during WWI. They came home safely on the Tuscania, September 1915. This article: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F60F13FA385B17... Mentions Miss Frances Coffey of Richmond VA among the passengers; the others' names are given as Miss Ruth Eddy, Miss Helen J. Martin, and Miss Edna J. Griffin. Miss Ruth M Eddy (b. 1886) was a member of a large family of Presbyterian missionaries in Syria; she was traveling to Cairo to work as a nurse at an English hospital. In 1937, Ruth Eddy was based in Worcester MA. Her brother was William Alfred Eddy (1896-1962), US Minister to Saudi Arabia in the mid-1940s: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_A._Eddy findingaids.princeton.edu/collections/MC041 www.condit-family.com/ps17/ps17_296.html

The Washington times., August 09, 1915, 5-30 EDITION, Page 12 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1915-08-09/ed-... indicates that Wood was president of the American Society of Aeronautical Engineers and had recently been nominated by the society to an advisory board for the Navy.
That is the same board to which Robert S. Woodward Thomas Robins and Alfred Craven had been nominated

Full name, Henry Alexander Wise Wood. Two more members: The Naval Advisory Board was a brainchild of the Secretary of the Navy, who asked Thomas Edison to lead a committee of the best American scientists. Each academy in each of the sciences was then asked to nominate two members to serve. Woodward was nominated through the American Mathematical Society , Craven through the American Society of Civil Engineers, and Robins through the Inventor's Guild. Wood and Sperry came in through the American Society of Aeronautic Engineers. books.google.com/books?id=1poSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA371&d... Dr. Charles John Hexamer, President of the National German-American Alliance www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=21124278

the NGAA, which Hexamer founded in 1901 and served as president until 1917, was forced to disband under political pressure in 1918, when American was at war with Germany. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_German-American_Alliance Hexamer was in the news on September 15, 1915 when, on behalf of his organization, he sent a telegram to all members opposing the proposed $1 Billion Anglo-French loan to the Allies as the work of "the Money Trust, the most sinister influence in our national life." He also advised members to withdraw their funds en masse from the banks in protest. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20814FE395D1673...

Virginia Myers (21 October 1906-) was a dancer before she was five years old. Her parents were artists in New York City (Jerome Myers was a painter, Ethel Myers was a sculptor), who encouraged their daughter's expressive movements with private, and eventually public, exhibitions. She danced for an early film. In 1916, there was a Vanity Fair article about her. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerome_Myers en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:BEDownes/Ethel_Myers ques.com/myers/html/virginia.html www.imdb.com/title/tt1056052/ A much later photo of her, still dancing: www.loc.gov/pictures/item/agc1996000079/PP/ This photo was used in a 1913 article about her, in Vogue: ques.com/ArtResearch/When%20Virginia%20Dances%20-%20Vogue...

"Arthur Gordon Webster (November 28, 1863 – May 15, 1923) was the founder of the American Physical Society." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Gordon_Webster

Webster was appointed through the American Mathematical Society to the Naval Advisory Board which was planning to have its first meeting in October, 1915 in the office of the Secretary of the Navy in Washington. Other Board members are also in the Bain newsstream, presumably in connection with their appointments to the Board, which was to gather the finest scientific minds to advise the military on use of the latest scientific achievements . A contemporary account lists his qualifications at the time of appointment as: "Arthur Gordon Webster, Worcester, Mass, Harvard '85, Professor of physics, Clark University." books.google.com/books?id=1poSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA371&d... "Tresco Abbey Gardens are located on the island of Tresco in the Isles of Scilly, United Kingdom. A Benedictine abbey was founded here in 964 AD, although the majority of what remains today comes from the Priory of St Nicholas founded by monks from Tavistock Abbey in 1114. The gardens were established by the nineteenth-century proprietor of the island, Augustus Smith. Because of the mild winter climate, the long hours of summer sunshine, and the high walls and hedges around the garden protecting it from the Atlantic winds, the garden is home to exotic plants from all over the world: the Mediterranean, South America, South Africa and Australasia." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tresco_Abbey_Gardens Panoramio photo by MHCharlton

"The Logan Rock (Cornish: Men Omborth, meaning balanced stone) near the village of Treen in Cornwall, England, UK, is an example of a logan or rocking stone. Although it weighs some 80 tons, it was dislodged in 1824 by a group of British seamen, intent on showing what the Navy could do. However following complaints from local residents for whom the rock had become a tourist attraction and source of income, the seamen were forced to restore it. Today the Logan Rock still rocks, but with much less ease than it did in the past." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logan_Rock panoramio photo by David Booth

From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newlyn "Newlyn harbour is the largest fishing port in England." It is in the far southwest, near Penzance. Recent view at motorboatsmonthly.media.ipcdigital.co.uk/9091|00000365d|9181_Newlyn-Harbour.jpg

This is the view looking east, towards Penzance (Cornish: Pensans).  Already famous as a fishing port, Newlyn became a fundamental reference point for the Primary Triangulation of the British Isles, when the Ordnance Survey established a Tidal Observatory here in 1915.  It has since become the reference datum for "Mean Sea Level" for all elevation data in the UK.

See www.francisfrith.com/bedruthan-steps/photos/ for lots of old photos of these rocks. According to www.intocornwall.com/engine/azabout.asp?guide=Bedruthan+S... "Bedruthan Steps are a series of dramatic rocky islands off the North Cornwall coast named after the legendary giant Bedruthan. The rock islands are believed to be the stepping stones which Bedruthan used when traversing this area of Cornwall. Dramatic cliff top views stretch for miles in both directions. Bedruthan steps have been a popular destination since the late Victorian period, when visitors to the new resort of Newquay enjoyed carriage rides here. The entrepreneurial local farmer charged for stalls for the carriages at 1 shilling per horse. Visitors walking to the site could enter free of charge. Individually named rocks include: Samaritan Island, named after the ship which was wrecked on the beach here in 1846; and Queen Bess Rock, believed to have once borne a resemblance to the Virgin Queen. "

AG is likely Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt. The "Mrs" is unclear to me. He divorced his first wife ca. 1909, and remarried 1911. He died on the Lusitania.

The widow was born Margaret Emerson, herself an heiress of the Bromo Seltzer fortune: "[Isaac Edward] Emerson's daughter Margaret married at 18 to Dr. Smith Hollins McKim. They became social leaders in New York's high society. But in 1910 she brought a sensational divorce suit against her husband, claiming he beat her in drunken rages. She remarried in 1911, this time to Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt I, one of the wealthiest men in America having inherited the bulk of his father's fortune in 1889. They had two sons, Alfred Gwynne Jr. and George. Tragically, while traveling to England on business, Alfred Sr. heroically lost his life in the sinking of RMS Lusitania by torpedo in 1915. Margaret inherited her husband's fortune (as well as the bulk of her father's fortune when he died). One son from this marriage, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt II went on to become one of the driving forces behind thoroughbred racing in America. Margaret married two more times, both ending in divorce. In 1931 she legally resumed her maiden name." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Captain_Isaac_Edward_Emerson Margaret Emerson's obituary from January, 1960: select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D06E4DD1138E333... A.G. Vanderbilt in another Bain photo:
hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.05295 is a picture of Mrs. Mckim/Vanderbilt from the Bain collection -- not yet uploaded to Flickr.
I haven't been able to identify this building. Sources I have consulted say she was living at the Vanderbilt Hotel at the time the Lusitania sank.

And I've found two houses she owned at some point but which it isn't: The Gould house on Fifth Avenue and Eat 67th shown in www.oldpokerchips.com/NonNevada/Gould.htm And a grand house in London, which he left her in his will according to NYT of May 30, 1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50B17F9385C13738... Gloucester House at Piccadilly and Park Lane pictured at www.amsprop.com/gloucester_house/index.html

I think the 67th st. and 5th Ave. house, was not owned by Mrs. A.G. Vanderbilt, but by Alice Gwynn Vanderbilt.

Louise Homer: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louise_Homer The baby is apparently Helen Joy Homer (1915-1946), later the first Mrs. William Main Doerflinger, the youngest of the six Homer children. She was always called Joy, but one of her wedding announcements calls her "Miss Helen Joy," and when her older sister Louise married in 1921, the youngest sisters Hester Makepeace Homer and Helen Joy Homer are listed as her flower girls. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60710F83A5B11728... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anne_Homer Joy Homer had an eventful short life: she was a medical relief worker in China, wrote a memoir of her harrowing journey on foot (Dawn Watch in China), edited Woody Guthrie's Bound for Glory, worked for the OSS in New Delhi during WWII; while in India, she was hurt in a car accident, and she eventually died from her injuries. She's buried in New York: www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~nywarren/cemeteries/bolton.htm

Thanks for the info!  We'll update record.

The Naval Advisory Board was a brainchild of the Secretary of the Navy, who asked Thomas Edison to lead a committee of the best American scientists. Each academy in each of the sciences was then asked to nominate two members to serve. Woodward was nominated through the American Mathematical Society , Craven through the American Society of Civil Engineers, and Robins through the Inventor's Guild. books.google.com/books?id=1poSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA371&d... Earlier appointees from 1915 to the Board, from the Bain collection: Matthew B. Sellers Elmer Ambrose Sperry A group photo of the Board's first meeting: select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E12F93C5D1773...

The mechanism on the starboard side of the breech and the lack of recoil carriage does suggest a machine gun. It certainly doesn't look like the 65mm piece. But I'm going to go with artillery because of the mount.

The gun then is a De Bange 80 mm cannon (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Bange_80_mm_cannon), probably with a shorter barrel (as it was made for the Serbian army e.g.: www.bulgarianartillery.it/Bulgarian%20Artillery%201/De%20...) and as shown here:

And I was sure that the thing at the side was the magazine for the cartridges.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05]  I first could not believe that it was an artillery piece - but you were right, it is one, not a 65 mm, but even a 80 mm gun

He's not this J. F. Archibald: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._F._Archibald James Francis Jewell Archibald was an American journalist aboard the Rotterdam in August 1915, when he was detained by British authorities. He was carrying papers that revealed a plot to disrupt American munitions production by fomenting labor unrest at plants such as the Bethlehem Iron Works. The "Dumba Affair" is explained in this entry on the Austro-Hungarian ambassador who was expelled as a result: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konstantin_Dumba

More speculation...Sauterelle is French for grasshopper.  The name is applied to a variety of man-made objects, in cluding woodworking tools, a boat,  a carnival attraction, etc.  Given the appearence of this thing, I can well imagine it being called a grasshopper.  It looks like it was designed to lob sandwiches from trench to trench.

Generalfeldmarschall Paul von Hindenburg was colonel a la suite of 3 Garde Regiment zu Fuss. A rare distinction so he wears the collar and cuff tabs of this regiment instead of the red and gold of a general. Only the crossed batons on the shoulders boards show his true rank. He wears the Pour le Merite with oakleaves at his throat and the Iron Cross 1st and 2nd Class.

This was part of the "Great Retreat", the Russian retreat from Galicia and Poland during World War I en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Retreat_%28Russian%29

American journalist, travel writer, lecturer: books.google.com/books?id=eloEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA49&d... This outfit seems to be an example of "Bifurcated Harleys," a trouser suit that Harley was promoting during WWI: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00C11F63A5C1B728... books.google.com/books?id=nVoEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA44&o... "Skirts are a disgrace to our intelligence, a badge of inferiority. ... My costume consists of two pieces, an upper garment and a bifurcated lower garment which I always designate by the name harleys. The upper garment is always worn over the harleys and fitted at the shouders, falls in graceful and natural lines to a point between the hips and knees and does not define a waistline. The harleys fitting easy around the waist and about the hips, slightly taper to the ankles, and cover each leg separately. The corset is absolutely eliminated. Ridges and rigidity would spoil the whole thing."

"Otto Praeger spent two decades as a newspaper reporter, rising to Washington correspondent for the southwest’s most influential newspaper, The Dallas News, before being named postmaster of the nation’s capital by U.S. Postmaster General Albert Sidney Burleson, followed by appointment as second assistant postmaster general for the nation, with responsibility for all transportation, including horses, trucks, the railroad and airplanes. " (from www.mavericksofthesky.com/the-air-mail-progressives/) see also: www.postalmuseum.si.edu/museum/1d_Lipsner_Letter.html www.postalmuseum.si.edu/airmail/airmail/coast/airmail_coa...

Another LOC photo of her, not from the Bain collection, is titled "Mrs. Bartlett Boder, one of first American women to drive an ambulance in European War, full-length portrait, standing, facing left' www.loc.gov/pictures/item/91794415/ Interviews with her appeared in several newspapers. She had been driving a three ton truck and ambulances in France for the British for 8 months when she arrived in New York on the liner St. Louis on September 12, 1915 when this photo was likely taken. She was 26, and from Whitestone, Long Island. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00F15FA385B17738... news.google.com/newspapers?id=UBJNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HUgDA... One source says she was a singer, performing under the name Mary Carter. www.ourstory.info/library/2-ww1/Hervier/volontaires1.html

She's mentioned in Ryan Corbett Bell, The Ambulance: A History (McFarland 2009), p. 122: "One of the first American women to go overseas in this capacity was the singer Mary Carter, who told a New York Times reporter in 1915 that she had volunteered with the Allies in January. In an article appearing September 13 of that year, the 26 year old told how she had been originally assigned to drive a three-ton truck for the British Transport Service but had later been given charge of an ambulance...'the first time I started it I knocked down a soldier because the machine jumped so quickly, and I had become accustomed to the slow movement of the three-ton truck.'...The intrepid Times reporter caught up with her as she steamed into New York to prove to her family in Long Island that, despite the efforts of the Hun zeppelins, she still lived, but she assured the reading public that she would be returning to the front, and her ambulance, after a few weeks of rest." And there's a caption mentioning her on p. 123: "Twelve years after Emily Dunning started her career as an ambulance surgeon, Mary Carter (Mrs. Bartlett Boder) became one of the first American women to drive an ambulance during World War I, chauffeuring a British ambulance truck at the front lines in 1915." books.google.com/books?id=-YtlthqHmHsC&lpg=PA123&... Looks like she divorced Bartlett Boder in March 1917; in August 1918 she married again, to John Williamson Lee (Harvard 1904). Their daughter Mary Lee died in infancy. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn90061457/1917-03-31/ed-... books.google.com/books?id=foUfAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA87&o... www.bklyn-genealogy-info.com/Cemetery/GW3.html A "Mary Carter Lee" was the sister of Frank Carter (c1888-1920), a popular Broadway performer, and was mentioned in an article about a memorial after his untimely death--seems like it could be the same woman. www.ibdb.com/person.php/person.php?id=34748 news.google.com/newspapers?id=MpQtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5ZcFA...

Excellent sleuthing. I see she was in the Social Register, living at a tony Manhattan address, into the 50's. Her husband died suddenly of heart disease at age 48 in 1931. He was the grandson of New York City mayor (1833-34) and the son of a leading leather merchant, Charles Lee. His real estate firm was called Lee & Carter. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50A10FB345E1B72...
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] I'm glad to know more about her later life!  Thank you.

Octave Homberg (1876-1941) was the main assistant of Alexandre Ribot, french Minister of Finance in 1914, he presided the currency board and negotiated the American loan. fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Famille_Homberg see: New-York tribune, September 11, 1915, Page 3: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-09-11/ed-... (O. Homberg described as member of French Foreign Office) "Sir Basil Phillott Blackett (8 January 1882 – 15 August 1935) was a British Civil Servant and expert on international finance." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basil_Blackett_%28civil_servant%29

The New-York Tribune article above indicates that the three were "ANGLO FRENCH FINANCIAL COMMISSIONERS CONFERRING WITH BANKERS TO
ARRANGE HUGE WAR LOAN FOR ALLIES."

Annual Report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York books.google.com/books?id=BJYpAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA40&lp... published in 1916, indicates that they arrived on September 10, 1915 "The Anglo-French commissioners, Lord Reading, Sir Edward H. Holden, Bart., Sir Henry Babington Smith, Basil P. Blackett, Esq., M. Ernest Mallet, and M. Octave Homberg, arrived on September 10 to discuss with American bankers plans to stabilize exchange. Further large shipments of gold were received from London via Halifax. Rates fluctuated irregularly. During the next month a firmer tone resulted from prospects of successful negotiations with the Anglo-French commissioners, but when the underwriting of the $500,000,000 loan was announced the market did not respond and weakness in sterling was accompanied by recessions in continental exchange. During the third week in October the publication of figures of heavy exports and large offerings of bills caused further weakness." Other pictures in this batch capture the delivery of a shipment of gold.

The Bankers Magazine, Volume 91, p 636 books.google.com/books?id=cXU9AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA636&l... has a piece on The Anglo-French Loan. An October 15 United Press report in news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19151017&... Indicates that these three did not travel together on the return trip. Hence this picture is likely taken when they arrived from Europe in September. books.google.com/books?id=5uggAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA757&l... reports that they arrived on the SS Lapland of the White Star Line. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Lapland

Jacob Ludwig Mathesheimer MD (man in the bowler) was based in Jersey City NJ; elected to the Medical Society of New Jersey in 1909; appointed lieutenant, medical reserve corps, US Army, July 1916. Emma Duensing (woman farthest right) died from meningitis and sepsis while on duty in Germany. She was born in Germany, trained at the German Hospital Training School in New York City, joined the Red Cross, volunteered for service in the Spanish-American War (she served in Puerto Rico and Manila); she was president of the German Hospital Alumnae Association, and treasurer of the New York County Registered Nurses Association. Because of her German birth, she was not allowed to go to Europe in an official capacity with the American Red Cross, and instead went as a volunteer. books.google.com/books?id=XIZBAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA34&o...
The sun., September 10, 1915, Page 16 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1915-09-10/ed-... reports, with picture (this one or one very similar), of their sailing on the Oscar II

There were several men with this last name invlved in the Mexican Revolution. From www.american-buddha.com/cia.soldierfortune.ch10.htm "In October 1914, Holmdahl was ordered to organize a small army to operate behind Villa's lines in Chihuahua. He formed an alliance with Jorge U. Orozco, a Carranza diplomat who was for- merly the Mexican Consul in El Paso. Also involved were Jose Orozco, a former colonel in the "Colorados" and a cousin of General Pascual Orozco, now in hiding somewhere in the United States, and Victor L. Ochoa, a Carranza agent." So this is likely the Jorge U. Orozco who was a Carranza diplomat, for- merly the Mexican Consul in El Paso

El Paso Herald (El Paso, Tex.), Ed. 1, Friday, October 15, 1915 texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metapth137468/m1/4/zoom/ [or chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88084272/1915-10-15/ed-... ] reported that he was on trial with others of violating terms of neutrality and organizing an expedition to Mexico. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/55876399@N07] The North Devon (and West Somerset) coast is special (to Brits at least, and even by the standards of the beautiful coastline scenery of SW England). Much of the coast consists of high cliffs, and access to the shore is often limited to small winding lanes and roads, and some of it only accessible on foot or by boat.  So it is quite a 'secret' coast. For this reason it is relatively undeveloped and unspoilt, even 'wild', and the few holiday resorts are quite small. The SW England Coast Path now gives foot access to all of it.
Excellent in one word !

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clacton-on-Sea in Essex, on the body of water that sailors know as the Thames Estuary, in the southeast of England. "Clacton Pier was the first building of the new resort of Clacton-on-Sea. It officially opened on 27 July 1871 and was 160 yards in length and 4 yards wide. Originally built as a landing point for goods and passengers, as Clacton was becoming an increasingly popular destination for day trippers, in 1893 the pier was lengthened to 1180 ft (360m), and entertainment facilities added. Bought by Ernest Kingsman in 1922, it remained in the ownership of the Kingsman family until 1971.[3] In March 2009 the pier was purchased by the Clacton Pier Company, who installed a 50 ft helter-skelter as a new focal point."

The building on the corner facing us is 1 Bridge Street. It is a Grade II* Listed Building. It is not particularly old, being late19th Century, and completed in 1888, i.e. not long before the photo was taken (there are much older things nearby: Medieval and Roman). However, its style is inspired by Tudor (16th Century) house building. I've always imagined the inspiration is Little Moreton Hall, a well-known 16th Century half-timbered mansion not far from Chester, in the same county (Cheshire).

Here in the US, a building from 1888 would be considered old and obsolete. A developer from out of town would convince the city to give him money so he could demolish it, promising to build something ugly that would "create jobs." Then he would run out of money and the site would be turned into a car park.

River Wye in foreground.  A famous view for British geomorphologists as it shows the development of a river meander as the river progressively undercuts the bank beneath the viewpoint leaving a record of older meander positions behind it.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/arden_loc] Glad to help. The River Wye in this area shows examples of this and various other classic geomorphological features (e.g. the river is 'incised' and 'superimposed').  The bedrock geology of the Carboniferous (Misissippian) Limetone exposed in the cliffs here, and also seen in other Chepstow postcards posted here, is also of geological interest.  But I assumed more information about these things would be more technical than you would want!

British scientists celebrated their feat of tracing a living descendant of a 9,000-year-old skeleton and establishing the world's oldest known family tree.

In an astonishing piece of detective work, they matched mitochondrial DNA material extracted from the tooth cavity of Britain's oldest complete skeleton with that of a 42-year-old history teacher, Adrian Targett. The genetic material showed without doubt that Targett is a direct descendant through his mother's line of the skeleton known as Cheddar Man, which was found in 1903 in caves in Cheddar Gorge in southwest England.

Most of the red buildings and the docks to the left still stand today and form the World Heritage Site known as Chatham Historic Dockyard along with the Ropery and many ships like HMS Caverlier. I live to the very left on St. Mary's Island that was once part of the Royal Naval Base, but the Royal Navy left in the 80's and Chatham Maritime as it is now known, is very different with homes, retail areas and 3 Universities!

The large square building top right is the Jezreel's Tower built by followers of the messianic James Rowland White in the 1880s. The Tower was a local landmark until it was demolished in 1961. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jezreel%27s_tower

This is taken from the north side of the River Medway at Upnor. The three large dock basins are still there and separate the green space to the left known as St. Mary's Island from the "mainland". The whole area is now known as Chatham Maritime since it has been redeveloped after the Royal Navy moved out in the 1980's. To the right many of the Iron grey buildings still stand and are in use and the red brick buildings are part of the 3 Universities who have facilities here. I know because I have lived on the Island for 16 years....

Katherine Drexel Dahlgren (b. 1894) was arrested for "speeding her automobile ninety miles an hour on the main street [of Stockbridge MA] and for operating the racer in a reckless manner," in July 1915. She married Richard Smith Emmet in January 1917; in July 1918, she and her sister Ulrica both gave birth to daughters in the same hour, at their mother's summer house in Ridgefield CT. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10F15FD395D16738... query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40817FD345C10738... One of her grandfathers: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_A._Dahlgren Her other grandfather: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_William_Drexel
I wonder how the constable clocked her speed...

This January, 1917 NYT photo supplement, at lower left, shows KDD and her bridesmaids: memory.loc.gov/service/sgp/sgpnyt/1917/191701/19170128/00... A picture in a news item announcing her engagement from September, 1916 shows her dancing on skates with her fiance and tells more of her racing exploits: "DARING SOCIETY AUTOMOBILIST TO WED DANCING PARTNER . New York, Sept 30. Mrs. Drexel Dahlgren has announced the en - gagement of her daughter . Miss Katherine Drexel Dahlgren, one of t h e most daring automobilists among the young women of society, to Richard Smith Emmet of this city. The announcement was made by Mrs Dahlgren at Fairfield, Conn., where she and her children passed t he sum - mer and will remain through the autumn . Miss Dahlgren startled summer residents of the Berkshire Hills about Lenox , Mass., a year ago by driving a 120 horsepower Mercer automobile at racing speed through the highways. She was fined $25 for this and was admonished for treating other local automobile regulations lightly. Later she offered to race George E. Turnure, Jr., on a motorcycle at Berkshire Fair Grounds. In society she has been active in Lenox and in this city, where she has appeared in various entertainments of the Junior League." fultonhistory.com/newspaper%2010/Kingston%20NY%20Daily%20...
grace!
Thanks artolog and pennylrichardsca for the information about this interesting woman.  We will add more details to the description when we update.

An account of the summer happenings among society at Lenox, Mass. in the New York Sun in the summer of 1915 has a very similar picture of Ms. Dahlgren in her car in what could be the same spot, but taken from the other side of the car. An accompanying article mentions that her race car was 120 horsepower, and she successfully defended herself from a charge that the car was too noisy by submitting that it was designed as an explosive race car, and that she would get it modified to make it more quiet. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%209/New%20York%20NY%20Sun/New... And in 1917, they were still talking about her: "In August of the same year she accepted a challenge to race her car against a motorcycle ridden by George E. Turnure, Jr. The highway authorities in the Hills were determined the race should not take place. Miss Dahlgren said:— "I simply couldn't take a dare from Mr. Turnure, particularly as I have driven my little yellow roadster at better than sixty miles an hour many times. If It is safe for a man to run a motorcycle at a faster clip than that, a girl ought to be able to go him one better with a powerful engine and four wheels. Mamma doesn't want me to take any risks, but dear mamma doesn't know that it is perfectly safe to drive a car fast when you know the roads perfectly. "All the village constables for miles around are watching us to prevent the race, but It will be over before they get through shining up their badges." New York Evening Telegram, Jan. 8, 1917 fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%206/New%20York%20NY%20Evenin...

Helen Frances Warren (1880-1915), wife of General John J. Pershing; she died in a fire at their San Francisco residence, with their three little daughters, in August 1915. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=5795509
pennylrichardsca:  Thank you for this sad information about General Pershing's family.  We will add some of the details to the image description when we update.

How sad. Here is the story as it appeared in a newspaper: GIVES LIFE TRYING TO SAVE CHILDREN ----- Mrs. John J. Pershing and Three Little Daughters Perish in Flames at Presidio ------ San Francisco -- Mrs. John J. Pershing, wife of Brigadier General Pershing and her three children were burned to death early Friday, August 27, in their home at the Presidio. General Pershing is at the Mexican border. The dead are: Mrs. John J. Pershing Margaret Pershing, aged 3 years. Ann Pershing, aged 6 years. Helen Pershing, aged 8 years. Mrs. Walter O. Boswell, wife of Lieutenant Boswell, instructor in the Athens Military School, Atlanta, Ga.; her two sons, Billie, aged 1 1/2 years, and James, aged 5 years; the 5-year-old son of Mrs. Pershing, Warren Pershing, and Florentine Perery, a Filipine maid, were rescued by officers and soldiers of the business men's instruction camp. Mrs. Pershing is a daughter of Senator Francis E. Warren of Wyoming. She is well known in San Francisco and has been a general favorite since taking up residence here. Fire was discovered raging through the building, near the parade grounds, shortly before 5 a.m. Mrs. Pershing sacrificed her life in an ineffectual attempt to save her three baby girls. She was found in a bedroom, baby Margaret in her arms, the other two girls clinging to the bedclothes. Mrs. Pershing was crushed under a heavy beam. Mrs. Boswell, a life-long friend of Mrs. Pershing was visiting at the Pershing home. Lieutenant Boswell, formerly with the Twenty-first Infantry here, has just been assigned to the Atlanta military school. He and General Pershing saw service together in the Philippine Islands, where Lieutenant Boswell acted as the general's aid. Mrs. Boswell and Mrs. Pershing graduated from Wellesley College in the same class, and have been taking a prominent part in the Wellesley celebration at the Exposition. Three hundred heroes, members of the army instruction camp, officers and soldiers of the post, three city fire companies and three from the Exposition fought vainly to save the lives of Mrs. Pershing and the children. Battling through smoke and flames, the rescuers dared a veritable furnace to bring the woman and children to safety. Their relentless efforts saved Warren Pershing. An investigation, which was started during the day by a board of inquiry appointed by Major H.H. Whitney, commanding officer, established the fact that the fire started from an open grate in the dining room, which was left piled hight with living coals when Mrs. Pershing and Mrs. Church retired shortly before midnight. Brigadier-General John J. Pershing returned to San Francisco Sunday morning, August 29, bowed, haggard, silent. He went at once to the undertaking parlors at Geary and Divisadero streets and for half an hour remained alone with the bodies of his wife and his three little girls, Ann, Helen and Margaret, who perished in the Presidio fire. From this flower filled room he went to look at the ruin of his house in the Presidio. He walked through the black and empty rooms and saw the bare beds and the path that the flames had taken in the night. He then went to the Letterman Hospital. Here he was greeted wit loving arms and the familiar cry of "pape, papa." His son Warren, 5 years old, the only one left, was waiting for him. They were left alone. The only thing that has consoled the boy in these last two days has been the fact that "papa is coming." His father had telegraphed him. The General returned to the Stewart Hotel for a brief rest. At 1:30, accompanied by Major-General Murray and the officers of the army post, he went to Gray's undertaking chapel, Geary and Divisadero streets, where Episcopal funeral services were conducted. The Rev. Dr. Edward Morgan, rector of St. Luke's Church, officiated. While the services were in progress a crowd of close to a thousand gathered in front of the chapel. General Pershing and his party left immediately after the services. An hour after the services the caskets containing the bodies of Mrs. Pershing and her three daughters were borne by the non-commissioned officers to two motor hearses outside the chapel. The caskets were in white cases, prepared for shipment. Six honorary pallbearers marched before them as they were being carried to the hearses. The non-commissioned officers acting as body-bearers did not march beside the hearses until the ferry was reached. They then formed in line and accompanied the hearses aboard the ferryboat Alameda, which left a 3:20 to connect with the Overland Limited. The train drew out of the Oakland mole at 4 o'clock. Accompanying General Pershing on his way to Cheyenne for the burial were his son Warren, Senator and Mrs. Warren, parents of Mrs. Pershing, and Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Warren. source: (The (Placerville, California) Mountain Democrat, Sept 4, 1915, page 4

Ottilie & Renaud Camus: Thanks for keeping us on our toes.  Back in 1905, the original Detroit Publishing Company sales catalog for these photographs categorized all the views of the Channel Islands with Great Britain, and we accepted that information too easily. On top of that, this particular photograph really is England. I've updated the description.  -- Helena (LOC)

Interesting that the post card says, lower left: 'Robin Hood Bay', but this well known and popular place (in North Yorkshire, YO22, UK) is now always rendered as 'Robin Hood's Bay' as on Google Maps and (most reliably of all) on British Ordnance Survey maps.  Other maps sometimes render the name without the apostrophe.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/20993969@N06] Is this question directed at my comment above? If so, then it's quite simple. The name seems to have changed a little (or just rendered differently) since this postcard was made (i.e. in the last 100 years or so), though it turns out that there are sometimes mistakes made with the name too.

Renaud Camus:  Thanks for catching the mix up in our use of England. The name "British Isles" might be our best bet for indicating a larger geographic association, since the United Kingdom designation also comes under question. 

For the readers who did not see your comment on a previous photo of the Channel Islands, here's the background. Back in 1905, the original Detroit Publishing Company sales catalog for these photographs categorized all the views of the Channel Islands with Great Britain / England, and we accepted that information too easily. 

The titles and descriptions for the Channel Islands photographs now say just "Channel Islands" and "British Isles."

NYT of June 30, 1912 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40C17F935581373... talks about a saucer-shaped "stadium motordrome" opening in 1912 -- for motorcycle racing. It says nothing about being a remodeling of the horse track (although that was adapted to motor-racing). So this may be a completely different stadium. NYT of May 7, 1912 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50F16FA3E581373... indicates that the new track for motorcycling was a perfect circle, 1/3 mile in circumference.

Several newspaper articles indicates that it existed a Stadium motordrome at Brighton Beach, also called "Brighton Beach Stadium" at least since 1912. e.g. The sun., August 26, 1912, (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1912-08-26/ed-...) New-York tribune., August 12, 1912, Page 8 (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-08-12/ed-...) That must be the stadium shown in the photo (but it's unclear to me whether this stadium was built on the ground of the former horse racing facility).
NYT of July 4, 1915 talks about reopening of the Motordrome -- "opening by the sea." select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E10F7395B1773...

Yes, this is the Brighton Beach Motordrome, though it was also referred to by other names. Chances are, this is showing the arena prepared for boxing, as the ring is in the center and the interior of the track is blocked out in sections. It is probably being prepared for the September 11, 1915 fight between celelebrated middleweights Packy McFarland and Mike Gibbons. Here's a NYT article describing the upcoming bout: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0DE3DD133FE233A... The New International Yearbook for 1915 said "The bout of the year which attracted the most interest in New York City was that between Mike Gibbons and Packey McFarland at Brighton Beach. The men battled to a draw before a $58,000 "gate." books.google.com/books?pg=PA95&lpg=PA95&dq=%22bri... Another Times article on the day of the fight gave further details, estimating a crowd of 40,000: select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0614F83A5C1373... It says the Motordrome is at the Brighton Beach Station of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Co. Here, the Bain picture is used in a story about preparing for the fight: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-08-22/ed-... New York Tribune, 8-22-15
Thanks to all of you for your great research and collaboration. We'll add some of the information about the fight to the record the next time we update.

New-York tribune., December 19, 1909, Page 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1909-12-19/ed-... announces his appointment as one of the assistants to district-attorney-elect Whitman. New-York tribune., November 05, 1914, Page chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1914-11-05/ed-... has him still as an assistant district attorney. New-York tribune., January 12, 1918, Page 14 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1918-01-12/ed-... has Wasservogel as a defense counsel. The bio pennylrichardsca linked to indicates that he was elected to the New York State Supreme Court in 1920.

In August 1915, it appears that he had been expected to be appointed to a vacant Supreme Court slot, but was passed over, according to NYT of August 22, 1915 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0E12F83C5D1773... NYT of December 29, 1915 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10813FE3B5B1773... reports his resignation as assistant district attorney and that he and another of the assistant district attorneys not staying on were to set up together in private law practice.

"Max Karl Wilhelm von Gallwitz (2 May 1852 – 18 April 1937) was a German general from Breslau (Wrocław), Silesia, who served with distinction during World War I on both the Eastern and Western Fronts" en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_von_Gallwitz It was attributed to v. Gallwitz to have said, after the Battle of the Somme about the brave fighting British soldiers: '„Nirgendwo sonst habe ich solch tapfere Löwen gesehen, die von solchen Lämmern angeführt wurden (Nowhere have I seen such Lions led by such Lambs)". This led (probably) to the movie title: Lions for Lambs (see en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lions_for_Lambs) There is no proof that v. Gallwitz is the autor of the sentence, though.

Additional information about Library of Congress images can often be found in the original record for the item in the Prints & Photographs Division Online Catalog ( www.loc.gov/pictures/ ). For a specific image, click the Persistent URL provided by Flickr, then click About This Item.

The IRT Ninth Avenue Line, often called the Ninth Avenue El, was the first elevated railway in New York City. It opened in 1868 as the West Side and Yonkers Patent Railway, a cable-hauled line. It ceased operation in 1940. The last section in use, over the Harlem River, was known as the Polo Grounds Shuttle, and was closed in 1958. This portion used the now-removed Putnam Bridge swing bridge and went through a tunnel, complete with partially underground stations. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IRT_Ninth_Avenue_Line

This is taken from the west side of 9th Avenue at 13th st. looking southeast toward Little West 12th St. . The white building across the tracks is still there: maps.google.com/maps?q=9th+avenue,+13th+street+and+hudson... In 1915, the line updated its express stops to a "hump express" configuration, where the center express track was elevated at the express stations. Wing and Son was a piano manufacturer located at between Hudson, 9th Ave and 13th St. The 9th Ave. El was demolished in 1940.

Lady Maitland is probably -- www.thepeerage.com/p8520.htm#i85198 "Gwendoline Lucy Vaughan-Williams was the daughter of Robert Vaughan-Williams and Sarah Jane Reid.1,2 She married Lt.-Col. Frederick Colin Maitland, 14th Earl of Lauderdale, son of Lt.-Col. Frederick Henry Maitland, 13th Earl of Lauderdale and Charlotte Sarah Sleigh, on 16 April 1890 at St. Georges Hanover Square, Westminster, London, England.1 She died on 30 January 1929." She painted miniatures. According to www.hull.ac.uk/php/cssbct/cgi-bin/gedlkup.php/n=royal?roy... she died in Florida. www.artfact.com/auction-lot/charles-goldsborough-anderson... gives some details about her in conjunction with a portrait by Charles Goldsborough Anderson: "Gwendolyn Lucy Maitland, The 14th Countess of Lauderdale signed 'C. Goldsborough' (lower left) oil on canvas 881/4 x 441/2 in. (224 x 113 cm.) Painted circa 1920 NOTES This magnificent portrait originally hung in Thirlestane Castle near the Scottish town of Lauder, the family seat of the Earls of Lauderdale for nearly 800 years. Painted circa 1920, Gwendolyn Lucy Maitland stands full-length holding a bouquet of blue irises and dressed in an ephemeral white gown. From the early 1920's the countess wintered in Palm Beach, Florida and at the time this portrait was made, she was already considered one of the leading figures of Palm Beach society. In 1926 she was even awarded the keys to the city of Fort Lauderdale, a city which she had claimed one of her ancestors had founded. She was one of the original investors of a real-estate venture in 1925 involving the development of a Broward county community north of Fort Lauderdale called Floranada. Conceived by her American ancestor Major William Lauderdale, the venture failed, most likely precipitating the sale of the painting along with other Lauderdale treasures."

The note on the right of the negative "Mrs. H. Goerlitz" indicates Amy Sherwin's marriage to Hugo Goerlitz, who in October, 1915 was managing the American tour of Stella Carol, who had in August of that year been in the news for surviving the sinking of the ocean liner in which she was traveling. paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=DO... "Young English primadonna" query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00D16F63E5D16738...

Stella Carol, age 17, a well-known soprano, and her husband, Albert Leblond, were passengers aboard the White Star Company Arabic when it was torpedoed without warning on August 20, 1915. The liner sank to the bottom of the Atlantic eleven minutes after it was hit. Approximately 175 passengers and 215 crew members survived the German attack. Stella endeavored to keep up the spirits of her companions in one of the crowded lifeboats by singing "It's a long way to Tipperary" to them, along with other patriotic songs – and she also lent a hand with an oar. Four years earlier, Stella Carol, whose real name was Lily Furnesse, and her sister were singing Christmas carols on the streets of Hampstead on Christmas Eve, 1910, hoping to get enough money to buy their mother a surprise Christmas present. By a wonderful chance she stopped to sing "Softly the night is sleeping" in the doorway of the well-known teacher of singing, Mme. Amy Sherwin. Madame Sherwin said, "I was much struck by the compass and the purity of the voice of one of the children. I called them in, chatted with them and made them comfortable. In the intervals of munching an apple, Stella, the elder of the two, told me she was thirteen years of age, one of twelve children, residing with their parents at Holloway." The following day Mme. Sherwin met with Stella's mother, and moved Stella into her home where she was provided with every resource for her education and professional training. A photo of Mme. Sherwin in the Library of Congress Collection on Flickr can be seen here: — Compiled and excerpted: New-York Tribune; The Straits Times; The Advertiser; The Dominion; The New York Times

Harper B. Smith took this one. His obit in the Bulletin of Photography for July 4, 1917, has this to say: "Harper B. Smith, official photographer for Atlantic City, N. J., and representative of the International Newspaper Photographic Syndicate of Underwood & Underwood, died on August 3d. He was 42 years old and is survived by a widow. Deceased had been ailing for several years, and eight months ago was operated upon, gaining temporary relief. Shortly after that time, however, Mr. Smith began to show visible symptoms of physical collapse, which ended in a light stroke of apoplexy. He rallied three times but steadily lost strength until the end came. Mr. Smith went to Atlantic City 25 years ago. from York, Pa., where he was born. He established himself on the Boardwalk, and for a long period was the leading man in the profession in the city. He devoted much of his time to doing work for the metropolitan newspapers, and was known to thousands of the resort visitors." books.google.com/books?id=khwoAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA174&...
